LOAN AND PROGRAM SUMMARY 

Republic of Indonesia 
 
Targeting Classification: General intervention 
Sector (subsectors): Public sector management (public administration, 

economic and public affairs management, public expenditure and fiscal 
management) 

Themes (subthemes): Economic growth (promoting economic efficiency 

and enabling business environment), governance (economic and 
financial governance), capacity development (institutional development) 

Location impact: National (high impact) 
Partnership: Government of Japan and the World Bank 
 
Category C 

 
This  Development  Policy  Support  Program  (DPSP-5)  is  the  fifth  in  the 
programmatic series of annual single-tranche operations in Indonesia. It is 
a  continuation  of  DPSPs  1–4.  The  DPSP  series—cofinancing 
the 
Development  Policy  Loan  (DPL)  series  supported  by  the  World  Bank  and 
the  Government  of  Japan—is  embedded  in  the  Government’s  Medium-
Term  National  Development  Plan  (RPJM)  for  2004–2009.  It  supports  the 
RPJM’s  broad  goals  of  stimulating  higher  and  sustainable  economic 
growth, with lower levels of unemployment and poverty, in three core areas: 
(i) investment  climate,  (ii)  public  financial  management  and  governance, 
and (iii) poverty alleviation and public service delivery to the poor. DPSP-5 
is  also  a  single-tranche  operation  based  on  completed  actions 
demonstrating satisfactory progress. It builds on reforms undertaken during 
past DPSPs and establishes policy actions for possible future operation. 
 
The primary rationale of DPSP-5 is to reinforce the Government’s efforts to 
improve  competitiveness,  enhance  public  financial  management  and 
governance,  and  contribute  to  poverty  reduction  and  improved  public 
service delivery to the poor. In addition, the DPL series aims to harmonize 
policy  reform  support  from  key  development  partners.  The  involvement  of 
the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  in  the  DPL  process  effectively  builds 
on and deepens reforms supported by ADB through its past, ongoing, and 
planned  operations  under  the  Indonesia  country  strategy  and  program 
2006–2009. 
 
ADB’s  participation  in  the  DPL  also  aims  to  improve  aid  effectiveness  by 
reducing  transaction  costs  for  its  developing  member  countries.  The 
approach is consistent with ADB’s reform agenda, as outlined in the long-
initiative. 
term  strategic 
Participation in the DPL helps implement and fulfill ADB’s obligations to the 
Paris  Declaration  on  Aid  Effectiveness  (March  2005)  and  the  Jakarta 
Commitment (2009).

Loan Amount 
and Terms 

 
Financing Plan  For  DPSP-5,  the  Government  has  requested  that  ADB  provide  a  loan  of 
$200 million.  DPSP-5  will  provide  parallel  cofinancing  for  the  World  Bank-
supported  sixth  DPL  (DPL-6),  for  which  the  Government  requested  $750 
million.  The  Government  also  intends  to  request  parallel  cofinancing  of 
$100 million from the Government of Japan for DPL-6. 
 
A single-tranche program loan of $200 million from ADB’s ordinary capital 
resources  will  be  provided  under  ADB’s  London  interbank  offered  rate 
(LIBOR)-based lending facility. The loan will have a 15-year term, including 
a  grace  period  of  3  years;  an  interest  rate  determined  in  accordance  with 
ADB’s  LIBOR-based  lending  facility;  a  commitment  charge  of  0.15%  per 
annum;  conversion  options  that  may  be  exercised  in  accordance  with  the 
draft  Loan  Agreement,  the  loan  regulations,  and  ADB’s  conversion 
guidelines; and such other terms and conditions as are set forth in the draft 
Loan Agreement. 
 
The  loan  will  be  disbursed  in  a  single  tranche  upon  declaration  of  loan 
effectiveness. 
 

 
Program Period  The  program  implementation  period  for  DPSP-5  is  from  January  to 
December  2009.  All  actions  included  in  the  policy  matrix  have  been 
implemented within the year. DPSP-5 fits within the overall reform agenda 
supported under the DPLs, which cover the period 2003–2009.

The  loan  proceeds  will  be  used  to  finance  the  full  foreign  exchange  costs 
(excluding local duties and taxes) of items produced and procured in ADB 
member countries, excluding ineligible items and imports financed by other 
bilateral  and  multilateral  sources.  In  accordance  with  the  provisions  of 
ADB’s  Simplification  of  Disbursement  Procedures  and  Related 
Requirements  for  Program  Loans  (1998),  the  loan  proceeds  will  be 
disbursed  to  the  Republic  of  Indonesia  as  the  Borrower.  No  supporting 
import  documentation  will  be  required  if,  during  each  year  when  loan 
proceeds  are  expected  to  be  disbursed,  the  value  of  Indonesia’s  total 
imports  minus  imports  from  nonmember  countries,  ineligible  imports,  and 
imports financed under other official development assistance is equal to or 
greater than the amount of the loan expected to be disbursed during such 
year. The Government will certify its compliance with this formula with each 
import  documentation  under  existing 
withdrawal  request.  Otherwise, 
procedures will be required. ADB reserves the right to audit the use of loan 
proceeds and verify the accuracy of the Government’s certification. 

  

iii

 
The  key  benefits  expected  from  the  DPSP  series  are  (i)  progress  toward 
the Government’s medium-term objectives of macroeconomic stability and 
creditworthiness,  an  improved  investment  climate,  better  public  financial 
management  and  governance,  reduced  poverty,  and  improved  public 
service delivery; (ii) raising the profile of key policy issues at the ministerial 
level,  accelerating  the  timetable  for  policy  actions  to  be  taken,  addressing 
administrative  and  bureaucratic  bottlenecks  to  reform,  and  providing  an 
impetus for decision makers to coordinate further across economic and line 
ministries;  (iii)  institutional  development  within  government  institutions; 
(iv) sustained ADB engagement in policy dialogue with the Government on 
the direction and content of, and strategies for, its economic, structural, and 
institutional  reform  agenda—with  DPSP-5  providing  for  policy  continuity 
and  consistency  in  sectors  where  ADB  has  been  actively  involved; 
(v) facilitation,  through  crosscutting  reforms,  of  reforms  in  sectors  where 
ADB  is  providing  or  planning  support;  and  (vii)  harmonization  and  parallel 
financing  by  the  key  development  partners  (ADB,  the  Government  of 
Japan,  and  the  World  Bank)  around  a  common  policy  framework  and 
dialogue, and the resulting endorsement of the Government’s sound policy 
implementation and macroeconomic management. 
 
Implementation of the DPSP series is subject to the following risks:

Indonesia  has  an  open  financial  system.  Domestic  residents  can 
switch  to  foreign  assets  easily  and  foreign  holdings  are  significant, 
especially in the stock market and in government bonds. Indonesia is 
thus vulnerable to shifts in investor sentiment. If significant funds are 
pulled  back  because  of  liquidity  demands  in  the  US  and  elsewhere 
and/or  increased  emerging  market  risk  aversion,  this  could  lead  to 
increased  pressure  on  domestic  interest  and  exchange  rates.  In 
addition,  the  Government  has  large  gross  financing  needs  over  the 
next  few  years,  and  tighter  credit  markets  and  increased  risk 
aversion  could  limit  the  Government’s  ability  to  tap  international 
financial markets. This could force the Government to cut budgetary 
outlays  to  maintain  fiscal  balance,  with  adverse  consequences  for 
infrastructure  investment  and  social  expenditures.  It  could  also 
distract  the  Government  from  implementing  its  medium-term  reform 
agenda,  including  those  supported  by  the  DPL/DPSP.  Several 
measures  taken  over  the  past  year,  including  bilateral  swap 
arrangements  with  the  People's  Republic  of  China  and  Japan,  and 
support  from  the  Public  Expenditure  Support  Facility  (PESF),  will

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Republic of Indonesia for the Fifth Development Policy Support Program (DPSP-5). The 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 

II. 

THE MACROECONOMIC AND SECTOR CONTEXT 

A. 

Macroeconomic Developments 

2. 
Indonesia  has  performed  impressively  since  its  emergence  from  the  Asian  crisis  of 
1997–1998.  Prudent  macroeconomic  management  has  resulted  in  moderate  inflation,  low 
budget  deficits,  a  sharp  decline  in  public  debt-to-gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  ratio,  and  a 
healthy  external  account.  The  rehabilitation  and  consolidation  of  the  banking  sector  and 
regulatory  reforms  initiated  since  the  crisis  have  buttressed  the  financial  sector.  GDP  growth 
has exceeded 5% in every quarter since 2005, reaching 6.4% in the third quarter of 2008 before 
succumbing to the intensifying global economic crisis. Progressively higher GDP growth has led 
to rising per capita real GDP, boosting the average Indonesian citizen's living standards.  
 
3. 
The  foundation  of  macroeconomic  and  political  stability  established  in  the  last  decade, 
coupled with the economy's high reliance on domestic demand, has helped Indonesia weather 
the  current  global  economic  crisis.  The  economic  slowdown  came  later  and  has  been  more 
moderate than in many other countries. GDP growth in the first half of 2009 decelerated to 4.2% 
year-on-year from 6.1% in 2008, but was higher than in most other countries in Asia. Domestic 
demand,  led  by  private  and  government  consumption,  was  strong.  Households  recovered 
confidence  as  real  incomes  were  supported  by  moderating  inflation,  the  final  tranche  of  the 
unconditional  cash  transfer  program,  and,  for  rural  households,  a  good  harvest.  By  contrast, 
investment spending slowed further in the first half of 2009, reflecting the growth slowdown and 
unclear prospects for the global economy.  
 
4. 
Inflation  decelerated  to  2.8%  in  September  2009  from  a  peak  of  12.1%  in  September 
2008, reflecting declining food and fuel prices, the lagged effects of the tighter monetary policy 
implemented  in  2008,  and  slower  economic  growth.  Indonesia’s  external  accounts  have 
improved in 2009; international reserves rose to $62.3 billion in September from $51.6 billion at 
end-2008. Merchandise exports continued to decline in the first half of 2009 with softer external 
demand  and  lower  international  commodity  prices.  However,  imports  fell  faster  on  weaker 
domestic  demand,  especially  investment  demand;  reduced  fuel  imports;  and  a  decline  in 
imported  intermediate  goods  used  in  export  production.  Portfolio  inflows  were  buoyant  in  the 
first half of 2009, following large outflows in the fourth quarter of 2008 when uncertainty in global 
financial markets peaked and investors' aversion to risk intensified.  
 
5. 
Indonesia's  banks  proved  resilient  to  the  current  global  crisis,  their  balance  sheets 
having  been  rehabilitated  and  strengthened  after  the  1997–1998  Asian  crisis.  They  had  little 
direct exposure to subprime assets when the current crisis hit. Banking indicators suggest good 
health overall. The capital-to-assets ratio is about 17%, and ratio of nonperforming loans is less 
than  4%.  However,  lending  growth  has  slowed  somewhat,  partly  reflecting  lower  demand  for 
credit with the slowdown in investment.  
 
The authorities' response to the worsening global economic environment last year was 
6. 
quick. Among other measures to stabilize the financial system, Bank Indonesia shifted monetary 
policy away from the anti-inflationary stance of mid-2008 by cutting its reference interest rate by 

 

  2 

300 basis  points  to  6.5%  between  December  2008  and  August  2009.  With  the  economy 
showing signs of recovery, Bank Indonesia signaled that its August rate cut was likely to be its 
last,  and  its  focus  has  since  shifted  from  supporting  demand  to  monitoring  the  outlook  for 
inflation in 2010.  
 
7. 
The  Government  adopted  a  more  expansionary  fiscal  policy,  including  a  stimulus 
package equivalent to 1.4% of GDP, in 2009. About 77% of the stimulus package comprised tax 
cuts for low- and middle-income workers, as well as to businesses.1  The remainder consisted 
mainly  of  spending  on  labor-intensive  infrastructure.  The  package  was  designed  to  provide  a 
quick  boost  to  domestic  demand  as  tax  cuts,  and  the  associated  increase  in  disposable 
incomes, especially of lower-income workers, were likely to be spent more quickly than capital 
expenditures, which are afflicted by slow disbursement.2 The higher deficit, coupled with large 
amortization payments on domestic and foreign debt, has increased the Government's financing 
requirement.

The  Government  has  made  significant  progress 

 
8. 
investment 
environment. Notable recent reforms include (i) the passage of the amended Income Tax Law, 
2008, which lowered tax rates, simplifies tax administration and increases legal certainty; (ii) the 
passage of the Tax Administration Law, 2007, which strikes a better balance between the rights 
and obligations of taxpayers and the powers of tax officials, an issue of longstanding concern to 
the  business  community;  (iii)  the  passage  of  the  law  recognizing  electronic  signatures,  which 
clears the way for multiple e-Government initiatives such as electronic registration and filing of 
tax  returns;  and  (iv)  the  passage  of  an  Investment  Law  in  2007,  providing  a  single  legislative 
framework 
time  required  a 
comprehensive investment negative list. Reform of customs administration is also underway. 
 
9. 
Regulatory  reforms  have  improved  the  ease  of  establishing  and  operating  a  business. 
According  to  the  Doing  Business  2010  survey,  Indonesia's  rank  in  overall  ease  of  doing 
business  improved  to  122  (out  of  183  economies)  in  2009,  from  129  the  previous  year.3  The 
time required to set up a business has fallen from 168 days in 2003, to 105 days in 2007, to 60 
days  in  2009.  Tax  reform  has  addressed  some  of  the  key  complaints  from  the  business 
community.  Reforms  in  tax  administration  have  halved  the  average  time  required  to  process 
value-added  tax  (VAT)  refunds;  in  addition,  more  than  Rp10  trillion  (roughly  $1  billion)  in 
outstanding  VAT  refunds  have  been  settled.  Doing  Business  2010  shows  a  decline  in  the 
number of hours required for an SME to pay applicable taxes, from 560 in 2005 to 266 in 2009. 
Partly  as  a  result  of  the  regulatory  reforms,  investment  rates  rose  from  below  20%  of  GDP  in 
2003 to 27.6% in 2008.

1   These  tax  cuts  on  income  were  in  addition  to  the  decreases  in  corporate  and  personal  income  tax  under  the 
Income Tax Law, 2008, which lowered the top marginal tax rate on personal income from 35% to 30%, reduced the 
number  of  income  brackets,  and  increased  the  minimum  threshold  for  income  subject  to  tax  by  20%.  It  also 
reduced the corporate tax rate to 28% in 2009, to be further lowered to 25% in 2010.  

2  The low leverage of households in Indonesia means that the increase in disposable incomes is more likely to be 
spent  than  saved.  Also,  the  marginal  propensity  to  consume  of  people  in  the  lower-income  bracket  tends  to  be 
higher. 

3   World Bank. 2009. Doing Business 2010. Washington, DC. 

 3 

It's important to keep in mind that the recent gains have occurred from a low base, and 
10. 
that  businesses  in  Indonesia  still  face  an  overall  poor  business  climate  compared  with  other 
countries.4  The  poor  relative  performance  partly  reflects  the  complex  challenges  Indonesia 
faces with its recent political transition, geographic dispersion, and decentralized policy-making 
framework,  among  others.  In  part,  it  also  reflects  other  countries'  progress  in  reforming  their 
investment climates. Indonesia’s rank in overall ease of doing business in the 2010 World Bank 
survey  (122),  for  example,  ranks  lower  compared  with  its  regional  peers—Thailand  (12), 
Malaysia  (23),  the  People's  Republic  of  China  (89),  and  Viet  Nam  (93).  Indonesia  ranked 
particularly  low  (161)  in  ease  of  starting  a  business.  Although  this  is  a  marked  improvement 
from 173 in 2008, and is higher than the Philippines (162), the country ranks substantially lower 
than Thailand (55) and Malaysia (88).  
 
Simpler,  more  efficient  procedures  and  lower  costs  for  business  entry  would  stimulate 
11. 
the  creation  of  new  companies,  foster  competition,  and  facilitate  the  transfer  of  workers  and 
capital across sectors, especially when economies experience sector-specific shocks. With high 
fixed costs of entry, firms also cannot easily move into expanding industries that are benefiting 
the most from trade openness. 
 
12. 
As  global  markets  become  more  integrated,  business  expansion  and  job  creation  are 
more severely affected by long, costly import and export processes. The delay in exporting by 
an extra day prior to shipping, for example because of cumbersome procedures, is estimated to 
reduce trade volumes by about 1%. For perishable agricultural products the reduction is nearly 
3%.  Streamlining  documentation  requirements,  providing  electronic  filing  of  trade  documents 
(through electronic data interchange systems), and using risk-based inspections are a few key 
measures  that  would  reduce  the  time  and  costs  of  importing  and  exporting.  Electronic 
transmission  of  documents  not  only  speeds  up  the  clearance  of  goods,  but  it  also  often 
improves  governance.  One  approach  for  speeding  up  trade  is  to  provide  a  single  window  for 
obtaining  different  permits  and  authorizations, 
time  spent  on 
documentation.  
 
13. 
Effective  implementation  of  investment  climate  reforms  has  been  slowed  by  poor 
oordination among  relevant  Government  agencies.  Uncertainty  about  the  legal  framework  and 
judicial  intervention  remains  high.  The  local  level  investment  climate  has  been  of  particular 
concern  because  of  inconsistent  and  often  arbitrary  regulation  imposed  by  local  governments. 
Recognizing  the  challenges  ahead,  the  Government  has  outlined  a  medium-term  reform 
agenda.5 The Government is placing a high priority on customs and trade facilitation, improving 
tax  administration,  and  continued  reform  of  investment  procedures  and  regulations,  among 
others.

14. 
The  public  financial  management  (PFM)  reform  program  has  progressed  significantly 
since the White Paper on public financial management reforms6 was published in 2002. A series 
of  laws  enacted  in  2003  and  2004—on  state  finance,  treasury,  state  audit,  and  development 
planning—provided the legal framework for subsequent reforms. A state budget combining the

previously  separate  recurrent  and development  budgets  has  been institutionalized  and  budget

ensuring  timely  availability  of  annual  financial statements  to  Parliament  and  to  the  public.  The

Public procurement has also witnessed improvements with the establishment in 2007 of 
15. 
an independent agency—LKPP (National Public Procurement Agency), which is responsible for 
planning and developing strategies, policies and regulations associated with procurement using 
public  funds.  The  roles  and  responsibilities  of  different  players  in  internal  and  external  audit 
institutions  have  been  clarified  with  Government  Regulation  60/2008  on  the  Government’s 
internal  controls.  The  Financial  and  Development  Supervisory  Board  (BPKP)  has  received  a 
significant  increase  in  its  operating  budget  to  fund  an  increase  in  the  number  of  auditors  and 
regional  offices.  Powerful  independent  oversight  and  prosecutorial  institutions  such  as  the 
Corruption Eradication Commission (KPK) and the Anti-Corruption Court have begun to deliver 
tangible results, and parliamentary oversight of budget processes has been strengthened. 
 
16. 
These  reforms  have  contributed  to  improved  governance  (Table  1).  According  to 
indicators compiled by the World Bank across six dimensions of governance, Indonesia's rank 
improved for all of them between 1998 and 2008. For political stability and regulatory quality, the 
country  temporarily  fell  in  rank  between  1998  and  2004,  reflecting  fundamental  political  and 
economic changes in the aftermath of the 1997–1998 Asian crisis, but by 2008 it had more than 
made  up  for  the  loss.  Its  progress  in  voice  and  accountability,  government  effectiveness,  and 
control of corruption is particularly impressive.

The achievements thus far provide a firm foundation for further progress, but significant 
challenges remain across the public financial management cycle, including budget formulation, 
execution, and reporting and auditing.7 While the budget has been unified for presentation and 
reporting  purposes,  the  budget  preparation  process  continues  to  suffer  from  a  de  facto 
continuation  of  dual  budgeting,  with  few  links  between  discretionary  and  non-discretionary 
expenditure, and insufficient emphasis on expenditure prioritization. The 2008 budget included

for the first time a medium-term fiscal framework based on aggregate macro-fiscal forecasts of 
both revenue and expenditures for 2 subsequent years.  
 
18. 
Input-based annual budgeting has contributed to problems in budget execution, causing 
expenditure releases to remain skewed toward the second half of the fiscal year. Some 50% of 
capital  expenditure  is  disbursed  in  the  last  quarter  of  the  fiscal  year.  This  disrupts  project 
implementation  and  results  in  under-spending  on  needed  infrastructure  investments.  Detailed 
input controls make it difficult to alter the budget during execution. Spending warrants (DIPAs) 
contain excessive amounts of detail, leaving little flexibility for adjustments in the composition of 
inputs needed to carry out a given activity. Reallocations across DIPAs from delayed programs 
to  better  performing  ones  require  lengthy  revisions,  sometimes  involving  parliamentary  review 
and approval. Spending agencies also do not effectively use their authority to reallocate budgets 
between  budget  line  items,  either  because  the  authority  has  not  been  clearly  understood  or 
because  of  an  inherent  preference  to  pass  on  the  responsibility  to  the  Directorate-General  for 
Budget and Directorate-General for Treasury.  
 
The budget needs to be structured along program lines, where the policy priorities can 
19. 
be  easily  identified,  and  where  the  results  of  the  programs  supported  by  the  budget  can  be 
monitored  and  assessed.  In  addition,  public  programs  must  be  sustained  over  a  number  of 
years.  A  strictly  annual  approach  to  budgeting  limits  the  Government’s  ability  to  plan  and 
execute  its  budget  in  a  strategic  way,  in  alignment  with  both  the  Government’s  priorities  and 
overall fiscal sustainability.  
 
20. 
The  budget  execution  process  also  suffers  from  fragmented  data,  inaccurate  and 
rudimentary  cash 
delayed 
management,  and  a  lack  of  information  on  program  execution.  While  a  uniform  chart  of 
accounts exists that is largely consistent with GFS Manual 2001, further strengthening of coding 
of programs, activities, and subactivities is required. The chart of accounts needs to be aligned 
to  performance-based  budgeting  (PBB)  and  the  medium-term  expenditure  framework  (MTEF). 
Refinements to transactions coding are required to capture commitments and payables against 
the line item in the budget for purposes of controlling and reporting budget execution.  
 
The  development  of  a  TSA  to  strengthen  cash  management  was  a  significant 
21. 
achievement,  but  operational  cash  planning  remains  at  an  early  stage  of  development.  Poor 
cash  flow  monitoring  has  perpetuated  year-end  bunching  of  expenditures.  Although  the 
institutional  setup  for  procurement  is  being  put  in  place,  the  legal  framework  for  public  sector 
procurement  needs  to  be  strengthened  by  anchoring  it  in  an  overarching,  consolidated,  and 
comprehensive national public procurement law.  
 
22. 
The  Government  recognizes  that  numerous  challenges  remain  and  that  ensuring  the 
coherence  of  future  reforms  while  maintaining  momentum  for  reform  is  crucial.  The  medium-
term focus of Government reform efforts is on restructuring budgeted programs and introducing 
an  MTEF  and  PBB,  improving  the  chart  of  accounts,  rolling  out  the  TSA,  implementing  an 
integrated  financial  management  information  system,  passing  a  new  procurement  law,  and 
improving internal controls and internal and external audit systems.

3. 

Poverty Alleviation and Public Service Delivery 

 
The  poverty  rate,  based  on  the  national  poverty  line, fell to 14.2%  in  March  2009  from 
23. 
15.4%  a  year  earlier, in  spite  of  the  slowdown  in  economic  growth.  This  reflected a  decline  in 
food and fuel prices, a strong harvest, and the Government's cash transfer programs to the poor 

 

  6 

and  the  near-poor.  But,  with  35  million  people  classified  as  poor,  the  poverty  rate  remains 
elevated. Furthermore, nearly 50% of the country's population are near-poor, living on less than 
$2 a day.8 
 
Regional disparities in poverty also remain.  For example, the poverty rate in Jakarta is 
24. 
4.6%,  in  contrast  to  a  rate  of  more  than  35%  in  Papua.  Services  are  unequally  distributed 
across regions, with an undersupply of facilities in remote areas of the country, partly reflecting 
an  underinvestment  in  infrastructure.9  Human  development  indicators  lag  behind  in  some 
dimensions—such as the high maternal mortality rate, malnutrition rate, and low transition from 
primary school to secondary school. Only 55% of 16- to 18-year-olds from the poorest quintile 
complete junior secondary school. A quarter of children below the age of five are malnourished 
and  Indonesia’s  maternal  mortality  rate  is  three  times  that  of  Viet  Nam.  Only  15%  of  rural 
households have access to drinking water from piped or pumped sources, and just 21% have 
septic tanks for disposal of human waste.  
 
25. 
 Post-decentralization,  about  one-third  of  total  public  expenditures  is  allocated  to  the 
district  level.  Yet  local  governments  have  weak  capacity  to  plan,  budget,  and  execute  public 
spending to improve the delivery of public services. In recent years, this has been reflected in 
increased surpluses run by local governments. Local governments and local service providers 
need to substantially improve their capacity to plan, budget, and deliver public services. 
 
26. 
The  challenges  are  to  build  on  the  foundations  of  macroeconomic  and  social  stability; 
and  accelerate  growth  to  reduce  unemployment,  poverty,  and  overall  levels  of  vulnerability. 
Over  the  past  few  years,  the  Government  has  launched  several  large-scale  programs  to 
alleviate poverty and improve access of marginalized groups to basic services. To insulate the 
poor  from  rising  fuel  prices  in  2005  and  2008,  it  implemented  an  unconditional  cash  transfer 
program which reached approximately 19.1 million households. In 2007 it began a 3-year scale-
up  of  its  flagship  poverty  program—National  Community  Empowerment  Program  (PNPM 
Mandiri). Village block grants are now being provided to every subdistrict in Indonesia.  
 
27. 
Building on the unconditional cash transfer program, the Government introduced in 2007 
a  pilot  conditional  cash  transfer  program  for  about  700,000  poor  households.  Funds  are 
provided  to  poor  families  who  obtain  preventive  basic  health  and  nutrition  services  and  send 
their children to school. In addition, the Government has invested in a range of social assistance 
programs  that  target  the  poor,  such  as  a  subsidized  rice  scheme,  a  school  operational 
assistance program, and a health insurance reform scheme.  
 
28. 
Such significant investments in a range of social assistance programs demonstrate that 
poverty  alleviation  remains  one  of  the  Government's  key  development  priorities.  In  addition  to 
allocating  more  resources  to  poverty  alleviation  programs,10  the  Government  will  continue  to 
pursue several critical initiatives to enhance the delivery and effectiveness of poverty programs, 
maximize the impacts of increased funding, and manage the impact of the global financial crisis 
on  the  most  vulnerable  segments  of  society.  These  include  (i)  improving  poverty  program 
evaluation and linking results with budget allocation and planning; (ii) introducing procedures to 
better  target  the  poor  and  marginalized  groups;  and  (iii)  empowering  local  government, 
communities, and service providers to deliver quality services.

III. 

GOVERNMENT STRATEGY, PROGRAM EVOLUTION AND RESULTS 

29. 
The  Government’s  national  medium-term  development  plan  (RPJM)  aims  to  achieve 
peace and security, justice and democracy while advancing the welfare of the people within the 
time  frame  of  2004–2009.  The  RPJM  is  focused  on  achieving  the  Millennium  Development 
Goals.  It  places  human  development  and  poverty  reduction  at  the  center  of  the  development 
agenda.  
 
To  help  implement  the  RPJM  priorities,  several  economic  policy  packages  have  been 
30. 
introduced  since  2006  that  specify  measures  to  be  achieved  within  a  defined  period.  In  2006, 
the  Government  issued  three  economic  policy  packages  covering  investment  climate, 
infrastructure,  and  financial  sector  reform.  In  2007,  a  comprehensive  follow-up  package  was 
issued detailing measures to accelerate development and empower micro-, small, and medium 
enterprises  (MSMEs).  The  latest  package,  introduced  in  May  2008,  builds  on  the  previous 
packages  and  details  reforms  in  the  following  eight  areas:  (i)  investment  climate;  (ii) financial 
sector;  (iii)  energy  security;  (iv)  natural  resources,  environment,  and  agriculture;  (v) small  and 
medium enterprises (SMEs); (vi) implementation of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
(ASEAN)  commitments;  (vii)  infrastructure;  and  (viii)  labor  policy.  Through  these  policy 
packages,  the  Government  has  demonstrated  its  firm  intent  to  address  several  complex  and 
politically sensitive issues.  
 
A. 

The Development Policy Support Program and Government Strategy 

31. 
DPSP supports the Development Policy Loan (DPL) series prepared by a joint team of 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB), the Government of Indonesia, the Government of Japan, 
and the World Bank.11  The DPL series aims to help the Government achieve its medium-term 
growth  and  poverty  reduction  objectives  through  three  core  policy  areas:  (i)  improved 
investment  climate,  (ii)  improved  public  financial  management  and  governance,  and  (iii) 
enhanced poverty alleviation and improved delivery  of public services to the poor. Building on 
the  support  provided  by  DPSP-4  (approved  in  December  2008),  the  proposed  DPSP-5  will 
provide  parallel  cofinancing  support  to  the  Government  to  help  implement  reforms  under  the 
sixth Development Policy Loan (DPL-6), the sixth in a series of annual, single-tranche loans.  
 
32. 
The DPSP series has allowed the Government to work with development partners in a 
flexible manner to implement critical high-level macroeconomic and crosscutting sector reforms 
that  address  constraints  to  growth  and  poverty  reduction  while  providing  predictability  of 
financial support. As such, its coverage is broad. Governance is a recurring theme throughout 
the DPSP series, as it aims to promote transparency in all of its core policy areas. The proposed 
DPSP-5 is anchored in the ADB Country Strategy and Program (CSP) for Indonesia,12 which in 
turn  provides  for  deeper  sector  interventions  to  complement  the  macroeconomic  and 
governance  reforms  supported  through  the  DPSP  series.  DPSP-5  builds  on  past  DPSP 
operations  to  support  the  Government  further  on  key  reform  measures  in  the  core  areas  of 
investment  climate,  public  financial  management  and  governance,  and  poverty  alleviation  and 
service delivery to the poor.

B. 

The DPSP Series, Other ADB Sector Programs, and Development Coordination 

33. 
The economic environment since the second half of 2008 has been marked by intense 
economic uncertainty arising from the global economic crisis. Still, as a sign of its commitment, 
the  Government  is  pursuing  its  medium-term  agenda  on  broad  structural  and  institutional 
reforms, while implementing measures to mitigate the effects of the global crisis. 
 
34. 
In  response  to  the  global  crisis,  ADB,  as  well  as  other  development  partners,  have 
assisted  the  Government  on  two  fronts.  First,  ADB  and  other  development  partners  provided 
contingent financing and support for fiscal stimulus to shore up market confidence and cushion 
the  impact  of  the  global  crisis  on  economic  growth.  Second,  they  continued  to  support  the 
Government’s  medium-term  reform  agenda  through  the  DPL/DPSP  process  and  sector 
programs.  
 
35. 
In  June  2009,  ADB  assisted  the  Government  with  the  Public  Expenditure  Support 
Facility  (PESF)  Program,13  which  is  part  of  a  joint  effort  with  the  Government  of  Australia,  the 
Government of Japan, and the World Bank to provide contingent budget financing in the event 
of further instability in credit markets that may result in a shortfall in budget financing. The PESF 
Program  included  a  series  of  confidence-boosting  policy  measures  aimed  at  sending  a  strong 
positive signal to the  markets, making it more likely that Indonesia would meet its commercial 
market  borrowing  targets  for  2009.  These  policy  measures  comprised  actions  to  (i)  reassure 
financial markets and maintain financial system stability, (ii) sustain critical public expenditures 
while maintaining budget discipline to mitigate the poverty impacts of the growth slowdown, and 
(iii) draw in private investment and support exports.  
 
36. 
ADB  is  also  providing  support  to  the  Government  for  its  countercyclical  spending 
program  for  2009  through  the  countercyclical  support  facility.  The  facility  will  help  ensure 
predictability  in  the  Government’s  budget  financing  given  the  need  for  a  temporary  fiscal 
expansion.  It  will  allow  the  Government  to  stimulate  economic  recovery  in  2009  and  2010, 
protect  its  social  spending  and  poverty  alleviation  programs,  and  continue  with  its  longer-term 
development  objectives.  Both  the  PESF  and  the  countercyclical  support  thus  complement  the 
DPL/DPSP series, which focuses on medium-term reforms.  
 
37. 
As noted above, support for the RPJM through the DPSP series is a key pillar of ADB’s 
CSP for 2006–2009. Under the CSP, a dual-track approach is adopted to ensure that the high-
level  macroeconomic  and  governance  reforms  supported  through  the  policy  dialogue  of  the 
DPL/DPSP  series  complement,  and  are  reinforced  by,  ADB’s  sector  programs.  Underpinning 
the policy dialogue has been a series of advisory technical assistance (TA) projects provided by 
the World Bank and ADB.  
 
Figure  1  presents  the  approach,  which  involves  structuring  ADB’s  support  through 
38. 
(i) participation  in  the  DPLs  to  strengthen  the  macroeconomic  and  fiscal  framework  while 
addressing  crosscutting  concerns;  and  (ii)  sector-specific  policy  interventions  in  the  areas  of 
infrastructure, financial sector, local government finance, and poverty reduction.

ADB’s  approach  aims  to  harmonize  and  align  development  partner  strategies  with 
39. 
Indonesia’s country strategy and priorities. The participation of (i) ADB and the Government of 
Japan in the World Bank-coordinated DPL series; (ii) the Government of Japan and the World 
Bank  in  ADB’s  Infrastructure  Reform  Sector  Development  Program;  and  (iii)  ADB,  the 
Government  of  Australia,  the  Government  of  Japan,  and  the  World  Bank  in  the  PESF  have 
helped reduce the Government’s transaction costs of policy dialogue with some of the country’s 
most important development partners.  
 
40.  Moreover, development partner harmonization around the Government’s own programs 
has bolstered country ownership of the reform process and helped nurture its relationship with 
development  partners.  ADB’s  active  participation  in  the  policy  discussions  in  all  areas  of  the 
DPL  and  the  parallel  policy  dialogue  on  PESF  and  sector  reforms  have  been  particularly 
appreciated  by  the  Government,  as  these  have  helped  in  setting  the  overall  macroeconomic 
framework for sector reforms, including those supported by ADB. ADB’s engagement in these 
policy  discussions  and  its  strength  in  the  areas  of  infrastructure,  financial  sector,  and 
decentralization have helped avoid duplication of effort and improved the monitoring as well as 
the quality of the DPL/DPSP triggers. 

C. 

The Evolution of the Program 

The focus of the DPL/DPSP series has evolved over the years, reflecting changes in the 
41. 
country's  needs  and  priorities  (Appendix  2).  At  its  inception  with  DPL-1,  the  emphasis  was  on 
ensuring  medium-term  macroeconomic  stability  and  building  the  basic  legal  and  regulatory 
framework for investment as well as public financial management and governance. At that time, 
the economy was emerging from the 1997–1998 Asian crisis, the country was graduating from 
the  International  Monetary  Fund  (IMF)  program,  and  fundamental  political  changes  were 
culminating  in  the  first  direct  presidential  elections.  The  DPL  was  expected  to  provide  the 
foundation  for  continued  medium-term  policy  engagement  in  the  areas  of  macroeconomic 
stability,  the  investment  climate,  and  public  financial  management  and  anticorruption.  It  also 
provided for a flexible means of taking into account the pace and fluidity of the reform process. 
As the program evolved, the scope of the Government-led reform agenda has been broadened. 
It  has  also  deepened,  whereby  successive  DPL  operations  have  built  on  previous  ones  to 
ensure steady progress in implementation.  
 
42.  Within  this  context,  the  main  focus  of  DPL-1  was  on  macroeconomic  stability  and 
creditworthiness,  investment  climate,  and  public  financial  management  and  governance. 
Reflecting  the  Government’s  success  in  achieving  macroeconomic  stability  and  attaining  the 
macroeconomic triggers of the DPL program ahead of time, the Government and development 
partners  agreed  in  early  2006  to  remove  the  macroeconomic  pillar  in  the  proposed  DPL-
4/DPSP-3, but to continue the policy dialogue on macroeconomic stability. At the same time, the 
increased fiscal space generated by (i) the reduction in fuel subsidies in 2005, (ii) declining debt 
service payments, and (iii) increasing revenues opened up opportunities for a greater focus on 
public service delivery as a new policy area. The DPL/DPSP operations currently focus on three 
core  policy  areas:  the  investment  climate,  public  financial  management  and  governance,  and 
poverty alleviation and public service delivery.  

 11 

D. 

Results Achieved14 

43. 
Policy  actions  under  the  macroeconomic  pillar  relating  to  debt  and  fiscal  policy 
management  contributed  considerably  to  lower  levels  of  debt  relative  to  GDP  and  a 
considerable increase in non-oil tax revenues. Rating agencies have also cited debt reduction 
and  the  Government’s  commitment  to  reforms,  including  changes  to  the  Investment  Law, 
customs and tax reforms, and fiscal reforms—all activities supported by the DPL/DPSP—as the 
reason  for  recent  sovereign  rating  upgrades.  Policy  actions  supported  under  the  investment 
climate have led to significant improvements in business start-up times and VAT refund times, 
and  have  led  to  the  establishment  of  a  sounder,  more  sustainable  financial  safety  net. 
DPL/DPSP policy measures have also supported revisions to the Tax Administration Law, 2007, 
the  implementing  decree  relating  to  tax  audit  procedures,  implementation  decrees  supporting 
the  Investment  Law,  and  the  gradual  rollout  of  a  national  single  window  (NSW)  with  online 
clearance of merchandise.  
 
44. 
A  key  achievement  under  the  public  financial  management  pillar  has  been  the 
implementation  of  the  TSA  to  improve  cash  management  of  public  finances.  The  DPL/DPSP 
program has helped move forward reforms to reengineer business processes across the budget 
cycle. The national budget is now compatible with the international standard GFS classification. 
Fiscal  reporting  is  more  comprehensive  and  timely,  and  a  medium-term  fiscal  framework  is 
gradually  being  introduced.  Initial  steps  to  address  civil  service  reform  were  taken  under  the 
DPL/DPSP  series,  resulting  in  an  overhaul  of  the  structure  and  remuneration  framework  for 
high-ranking  state  officials.  A  task  force  was  set  up  to  examine  the  entire  compensation 
package with the goal of creating a more transparent, systematic, and coherent framework for 
pay  and  allowances  based  on  a  comprehensive  job  evaluation  and  pay  grading.  Building  on 
this, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) has developed a comprehensive civil service reform action 
plan, which is being pilot-tested in other agencies.  
 
Important  steps  were  also  established  under  the  DPL/DPSP  series  to  help  lay  the 
45. 
groundwork for improving poverty targeting of basic services. As the 2005 fuel price hike made 
more  resources  available  for  social  spending,  the  DPL/DPSP  supported  building  capacity  in 
government institutions to strengthen the evaluation function in order to improve the targeting of 
these released funds. Lessons from targeting were then incorporated into the new cash transfer 
program  that  accompanied  the  May  2008  fuel  price  increase.  DPSP/DPL  has  also  supported 
critical  actions  to  improve  the  quality  of  public  service  delivery  in  education  and  community-
based development. 

E. 

Lessons 

46. 
Development  coordination.  The  DPL/DPSP  facility  provided  a  useful  platform  for 
coordination  of  development  partners'  policies  and  programs.  The  Government  welcomed  the 
development  of  a  consistent  approach  among  key  development  partners  to  critical  reform 
issues.  Sharing  of  technical  advisory  support,  information,  and  data  also  had  implications  for 
cooperation  in  other  operational  areas,  most  notably  in  programs  to  support  infrastructure 
development, where ADB took the lead role (Appendix 6). 
 
47. 
Coordination within Government. The negotiations to develop the DPL/DPSP and the 
need  to  develop  joint  positions  on  policy  issues  necessitated  regular  and  continuous 

                                                 
14  This  section,  and  the  subsequent  section  on  lessons,  is  based  on  the  findings  of  program  completion  reports 

undertaken for DPSP-1 in 2008, and for DPSPs 2–3 in 2009 (Appendix 3 provides more details on results). 

 

  12 

interagency  consultation  and  coordination  that  may  have  contributed  to  improvements  in  the 
policy coordination process within and across key agencies of the Government.  
 
48. 
Design  and  specification  of  specific  triggers.  Policy  triggers  were  defined  on  the 
basis  of  mutual  trust  and  understanding  between  the  Government  and  the  three  development 
partners, with a clear understanding of the direction of reforms, without excessive specificity that 
would create political difficulties or compromise the flexibility of the Government in overcoming 
obstacles to reform.15 This was especially important in areas where the Executing Agency, the 
Coordinating Ministry for Economic Affairs (CMEA), or the agencies working most closely with 
it—MOF and the National Development Planning Agency (BAPPENAS)—had no direct control 
over implementation of a particular reform, as other agencies or Parliament were involved. 
 
Role of policy triggers. The triggers comprise part of the Government-owned and led 
49. 
reform program. The choice of triggers was important in guiding both the direction and pace of 
the  reform  process.  The  inclusion  of  a  trigger  in  the  DPL/DPSP  was  welcomed  by  those 
advancing  particular  reforms  within  the  Government,  as  this  would  increase  the  profile  of  the 
reform and could help ensure maintenance of the momentum needed to achieve the reform.  
 
50. 
Importance of continuity in the reform process, building on earlier changes. Some 
reforms  led  to  solid  progress  on  a  reform  objective,  and  the  DPL/DPSP  played  a  clear  role  in 
their achievement. In PFM, for example, the DPL/DPSP support for the TSA led to a significant 
improvement  in  cash  management,  setting  the  stage  for  better  cash  planning.  These  reforms 
are also more sustainable, as the reforms were institutionalized as they progressed, and as the 
parties involved remained engaged in the reform process. 
 
51. 
Strengthening  change  management  capacity  in  the  Government.  The  success  of 
the DPL/DPSP programs has hinged on the proactive role taken by key counterparts willing to 
take up difficult change management functions. This has necessitated a strong communications 
strategy  with  all  concerned  stakeholders.  Assessing  the  potential  gains  and  losses  for  key 
stakeholders, realistically assessing the time frames required to implement specific actions, and 
identifying potential obstacles, risks, and remedial actions to be taken have all been vital to the 
process.  It  was  widely  recognized  in  the  DPL/DPSP  process  that  supporting  the  agencies 
leading  the  reform  process  through  advisory  services  or  technical  support  would  yield  greater 
benefits  in  terms  of  the  design  and  facilitation  of  future  reforms.  DPL/DPSP  reforms  have 
tended to be most successful in areas where they were complemented by a strong TA program. 
 

                                                 
15 In  keeping  with  the  programmatic  DPL  modality,  which  has  been  characterized  by  medium-term  engagement, 
strong  country  ownership,  and  continuous  policy  dialogue  with  the  Government,  triggers  are  used  in  a  more 
process-oriented  and  flexible  sense  with  less  of  a  focus  on  compliance  with  conditions.  International  experience 
with  policy-based  lending  and  recent  literature  on  the  subject  suggests  that  a  focus  on  traditional  conditionality 
could undermine country ownership and the sustainability of the reform process (World Bank. 2005. Conditionality 
Revisited. Washington, DC; ADB. 2007. Special Evaluation Study on Policy-Based Lending: Emerging Practices in 
Supporting Reforms in Developing Member Countries. Manila).

IV. 

THE PROPOSED PROGRAM 

A. 

Impact and Outcome 

52. 
The  DPSP-5  will  contribute  to  higher  pro-poor  economic  growth  that  is  sustained  over 
the  medium  term.  The  expected  outcome  of  the  Program  will  be  improved  overall  economic 
management  anchored  on  good  governance.  The  Program's  outputs,  which  will  underpin  the 
outcome,  are  (i)  improved  investment  climate,  (ii)  improved  public  financial  management  and 
governance, and (iii) enhanced poverty alleviation and public service delivery to the poor.  
 
53. 
DPSP-5 is in Appendix 5. 

The  development  policy  letter  is  provided  in  Appendix  4,  and  the  policy  matrix  for  the 

B. 

Policy Framework and Actions 

DPSP-5  is  substantively  a  continuation  of  DPSPs  1–4,  the  programmatic  series  of 
54. 
annual  single-tranche  operations  from  2005  to  2008.  It  continues  the  policy  dialogue  on,  and 
support  to,  the  Government's  reform  program  in  the  three  core  areas  that  were  the  focus  of 
DPSP-4:  (i)  the  investment  climate,  (ii)  public  financial  management  and  governance,  and 
(iii) enhanced  poverty  alleviation  and  public  service  delivery  to  the  poor.  Improvements  in  the 
investment  climate  are  critical  to  accelerating  growth.  Enhanced  public  financial  management 
and governance are essential for increasing the effectiveness of the Government's policies and 
programs. Improving service delivery to the poor and poverty alleviation efforts are important if 
Indonesia is to bring about more broad-based improvements in welfare for its population.  
 
55. 
The  triggers  in  these  three  areas  were  chosen  as  part  of  the  dialogue  with  the 
Government during preparation of DPSP-4, and represent a natural progression from those that 
were  achieved  in  that  program.  The  DPSP-4  program  document  laid  out  12  indicative  policy 
triggers  across  eight  policy  areas  for  DPSP-5.  Subsequently,  the  Government  and  its 
development partners agreed to merge the trigger on "drafting key performance indicators for all 
budgeted  programs"  with  another  on  developing  a  revised  program  structure  for  RPJM  2010–
2014, since the former was an integral part of the latter. Furthermore, the trigger on updating the 
regulation on investment negative list (para. 59) was revised in early 2009 to take into account 
the drafting of the revised regulation that was included as part of the policy action for the PESF. 
All of the triggers under the proposed program registered satisfactory progress (Table 2).

clarify regulations for investors, reduce the cost of complying with the regulations by making the 
process of compliance more efficient, improve tax administration, and increase SMEs' access to 
finance.

Before the 2007 Investment Law was passed, the investment negative list (DNI) allowed 
substantial scope for ministries and agencies to impose ad hoc restrictions. These restrictions 
were poorly documented; lacked a clear, legal basis; could be applied on a case-by-case basis; 
and  often  contradictory.  The  2007  law  required  the  issuance  of  a  presidential  regulation  on  a 
new DNI. This new list was more detailed and comprehensive and hence more transparent. But

Moreover,  it  raised  new  issues  with  regard  to  the  treatment  of  publicly  listed  companies,  the 
creation of restrictions outside the DNI, international commitments, and a grandfathering clause 
for existing investors. In response to concerns raised by the Indonesian Chamber of Commerce, 
the  Government  committed  in  2008  to  further  simplify  the  list  and  address  specific 
shortcomings. 
 
58. 
The original trigger for DPSP-5 called for monitoring and assessing the DNI and issuing 
supporting regulations. It did not call for a revision of the presidential regulation on the DNI. As a 
prior  action  for  the  PESF,  the  Government  drafted  a  new  revised  presidential  regulation  in 
February  2009  and  discussed  it  with  stakeholders,  including  the  business  community.  The 
Government  subsequently  initiated  an  interministerial  review  of  the  draft.  Considering  the 
progress  made  under  the  PESF,  the  Government  and  the  development  partners  agreed  to 
replace the original trigger for DPL-6/DPSP-5 with a policy  action calling for completion of the 
interministerial review and the endorsement of the draft by the ministerial plenary session.  
 
The draft was endorsed by a plenary meeting of 20 ministers in July 2009. According to 
59. 
the  draft,  some  70  business  activities  will  become  less  restrictive  compared  with  the  2007 
regulation,  while  eight  activities  will  become  more  restrictive.  Investment  regulations  on  59 
activities  will  be  clarified.  Ownership  limits  on  about  40  types  of  construction  works  were 
increased  from  55%  to  67%,  and  construction  consultancy  services  were  moved  from  the  list 
reserved  for  micro-,  small,  and  medium-sized  enterprises  to  the  list  with  an  ownership  limit  of 
55%. Equity limits on a number of tourism activities were increased from 50% to 51%. Among 
the  activities  that  were  made  more  restrictive,  five  types  of  security  services,  which  were 
previously  excluded  from  the  DNI,  were  included  in  the  draft  revised  regulation  with  a  49% 
ownership  limit  and  a  requirement  to  obtain  a  license  from  the  national  police;  two  were  in 
agriculture and one was in tourism.  
 
The draft regulation clarifies that (i) provisions on the DNI will not apply to investments

original  letter  of  approval,  and  (ii)  publicly  listed  companies  are  excluded  from  the  DNI.  The

The  2007  Investment  Law  stipulates  issuance  of  a  presidential  regulation  on  one-door 
61. 
integrated  investment  service,  or  one-stop  shops  (PTSPs).  The  presidential  regulation  on 
PTSPs  was  issued  on  23  June  2009.  The  new  regulation  allows  ministries  and  central 
Government agencies to turn over or delegate their authority to issue business licenses to the 
National  Investment  Coordinating  Board  (BKPM).  It  authorizes  BKPM  to  establish  a  one-stop 
shop for investment licensing as well as an electronic information and licensing service. At the 
local government level, the regulation requires that business licensing authority be transferred to 
local one-stop shops, and it empowers BKPM to monitor the implementation and performance 
of the local one-stop shops.  
 
62. 
Since  the  technical  skills  to  assess  license  applications  lie  with  the  ministries  and 
agencies that regulate each sector, the challenge will be to reach agreement on which licenses 
can  be  transferred  to  BKPM’s  new  one-stop  shop  without  compromising  the  quality  of  the 
licensing process. Following the issuance of this PTSP regulation, detailed technical regulations 
for  investment  within  each  sector  will  be  required.  An  online  investment  licensing  system 
technical  team  has  been  established  and  a  work  plan  agreed  upon.  The  online  system,  to  be 
made  accessible  to  the  public  within  3  years,  will  connect  (i)  licenses  already  delegated  to 
BKPM  and  further  delegated  to  subnational  governments;  (ii)  licenses  by  subnational 
governments;  and  (iii)  licenses  under  the  authority  of  line  ministries.  A  prerequisite  for  the 
smooth  functioning  of  the  new  system  will  be  the  mapping  and  subsequent  simplification  of 
existing business licensing systems and a reduction in the number of licenses required. Going 
forward, the DPL series will continue to support implementation of the PTSPs. 
 

c. 

Trigger 3: Finalize a draft proposal for the operational model and 
governance structure of the Indonesia NSW. (current status: satisfactory) 

 
63. 
The  NSW  for  imports  and  exports  is  the  most  important  trade  facilitation  initiative 
underway in Indonesia. Under a fully operational single window system, traders (importers and 
exporters)  will  no  longer  be  required  to  apply  individually  to  multiple  government  agencies—
such  as  customs,  the  port  authority,  the  Ministry  of  Trade,  the  Food  and  Drug  Agency,  and 
quarantine—to  clear  cargoes.  A  single  application  is  instead  submitted  using  a  single 
administrative document and this application is then transmitted to each relevant agency by the 
operator  of  the  single  window.  Approval  is  transmitted  back  to  the  operator  so  that  the  trader 
communicates directly with one authority rather than multiple authorities. The Indonesia NSW is 
being established in the framework of several ASEAN agreements as an initial step toward an 
eventual ASEAN single window for international trade. 
 
64. 
Eight  government  agencies  are  currently  implementing  steps  toward  the  Indonesia 
NSW, with  customs as the lead agency, until the operational model and governance structure 

 17 

for the NSW is established and the operator is selected. The agencies have begun to revamp 
their business processes to work toward a single submission and single approval of applications 
by traders.  In December 2008 these processes became mandatory for imports in Tanjung Priok 
and Semarang. During  July 2009 they became mandatory  for imports in Surabaya and a pilot 
has been launched for exports in the same port.  
 
65. 
The  decision  on  the  operational  model  and  the  governance  structure  for  the  Indonesia 
NSW  was  originally  scheduled  for  December  2008.  However,  the  requisite  donor-funded 
technical  assistance  came  in  place  only  in  February  2009,  and  the  need  to  refine  further  the 
operational model recommended by experts under the TA has meant that the process has been 
delayed by about 1 year.  
 
A draft proposal for the operational model was submitted to the coordinating minister for 
66. 
economic  affairs  in  August  2009.  This  included  a  detailed  institutional  structure  for  an 
independent  entity  to  oversee  the  NSW,  comprising  a  governing  council  with  representatives 
from  15  ministries  and  agencies;  a  chief  executive  officer;  a  Secretariat;  and  one  division  for 
policy  and  one  for  technical  and  operational  matters.  The  latter  division  will  select  the  NSW 
operator.  There  are  also  three  units  under  each  participating  ministry  for  policy,  customer 
interface, and for technical and operational matters, which, among other tasks, will develop the 
electronic platform linking the agency with the NSW. A final decision on the operational model 
and  governance  structure  is  expected  to  be  made  in  early  2010.  Selection  of  the  operator  is 
supported by the next DPL.

67. 
In an effort to strike an appropriate balance between taxpayer service and enforcement, 
the  Directorate  General  (Tax)  has  embarked  on  a  major  reform  process  to  modernize  its 
organizational  structure  and  to  introduce  a  modern  compliance  management  approach.  It  has 
successfully  restructured  its  headquarters  by  moving  from  a  “tax  type”  to  one  classified 
according  to  functions  (registration,  returns  processing,  etc.).  It  is  establishing  a  field  office 
network targeted to specific taxpayer segments (large, medium, and small taxpayer offices). It 
has  also 
improve  voluntary  compliance. 
Accomplishments  include  increasing  taxpayer  registration,  increasing  tax  return  filings  by  new 
and  existing  taxpayers,  the  recovery  of  tax  arrears,  and  the  introduction  of  e-registration  and 
e-filing. The number of registered taxpayers, comprising mainly individuals, increased from 4.4 
million in 2005 to 7.1 million in 2007 and an estimated 15.1 million in 2009. 
 
68. 
The issuance in December 2008 of the decree allowing recognition of digital signatures 
for individual taxpayer registration and for filing personal income tax returns has permitted the 
rollout  of  e-registration  and  e-filing  for  taxpayers.  Subsequently,  the  Directorate  General  (Tax) 
issued  a  new  regulation  (no.  24/PJ/2009)  to  enable  electronic  tax  registration.  The  regulation 
specifies the procedures for electronic registration with a taxpayer identification number and/or 
VAT  collector  number.  Replacing  paper  filing  with  electronic  filing  will  reduce  taxpayer  burden 
and filing costs.

Trigger 6: Issue Ministry of Finance regulation on credit guarantee and 
re-guarantee companies. (current status: achieved) 

 
71.   Access to credit is still widely regarded as a major constraint to the growth of MSMEs in 
Indonesia.  Numerous  line  ministries  and  state-owned  enterprises  have  tried  to  run  several 
schemes  for  MSMEs  with  limited  success.  MSMEs  with  viable  business  models  do  not  have 
access to bank credit for several reasons, including lack of collateral and limited understanding 
by  the  banks  about  the  enterprises'  business  risks.  In  2007,  the  Government  moved  toward 
rationalizing all SME financing programs of line ministries into a unified guarantee facility—the 
Kredit  Usaha  Rakyat  (People’s  Entrepreneurship  Credit  Program).  Under  the  Kredit  Usaha 
Rakyat, the banks assume 30% of the credit risk and the credit guarantee facility assumes the 
remaining  70%.  In  addition,  following  the  issuance  in  January  2008  of  Government  regulation 
(PP)  no.2/2008,  which allows  for  the  establishment  of  national  and  provincial  credit  guarantee 
and  re-guarantee  companies,  the  Ministry  of  Finance  issued  an  implementing  regulation 
(222/2008)  in  December  2008  that  clarifies,  among  other  things,  the  legal  status  of  these 
companies, their ownership structure, reporting mechanisms, and investment options. Under the 
new regulation, both private and state-owned credit guarantee and re-guarantee companies can 
be established at the national and provincial level.

To  improve  the  results  orientation  of  the  budget  process,  BAPPENAS  and  MOF  have 
73. 
committed to developing a revised program structure that will be used in the medium-term plan 
(RPJM  2010-2014)  to  be  implemented  by  the  new  Government  and  to  be  issued  in  2010.  On 
19 June 2009, a joint circular was signed by both the finance and planning ministers stating that 
a  revised  results-based  program  structure  is  to  be  implemented  by  the  76  ministries  and 
ministry-level agencies in the process of developing the 2010–2014 RPJM and the Ministry and 
Agency  Medium-Term  Strategic  Plan  (Renstra-KL).  This  is  a  critical  first  step  in  achieving  the 
goal of a results-based budget. The programs and activities in the revised structure would have 
measurable  results  and  targets,  and  the  activities  related  to  policy  priorities  should  be 
identifiable. 
 
74. 
BAPPENAS  and  MOF  launched  on  14  July  2009  a  manual  on  performance-based 
budgeting (PBB) within the MTEF that provides guidance to line ministries for the preparation of 
the revised program structure of their medium-term plans. Dissemination of the PBB/MTEF joint 
manual  and  consultations  on  the  new  program  structures  and  activities  are  ongoing.  The 
PBB/MTEF  joint  manual  also  includes  detailed  guidance  on  how  to  develop  key  performance 
indicators  for  budgeted  programs  with  appropriate  targets  over  a  given  time  period.  Key 
performance  indicators  would  help  monitor  the  outputs  and  outcomes  of  public  expenditures 
and programs, and track their progress. It is expected that the final versions of the new program 
structures, activities, and key performance indicators for all 76 budget holders will be completed 
by December 2009.  
 

b. 

Trigger 8: Implement daily sweep of revenue accounts into the TSA for 
all commercial banks. (current status: achieved) 

 
75. 
Under  its  treasury  management  program,  the  Government  has  continued  to  expand 
implementation of the TSA to consolidate all government bank accounts. Regulations issued in 
2007  authorized  MOF  to  bring  all  government  bank  accounts  under  the  TSA.  Since  2007,  the 
TSA  for  expenditure  management  has  been  made  operational  in  all  MOF  Treasury  offices. 
However,  an  annual  census  of  the  government  bank  accounts  revealed  that  a  significant 
number of accounts are still outside the coverage of the TSA. The TSA has now been extended 
to cover most of the imprest bank accounts currently owned by budgetary institutions for petty 
cash and salary payments. 

76. 
The  consolidation  of  the  TSA  has  advanced  significantly  since  2008.  MOF  and  Bank 
Indonesia  have  signed  a  memorandum  of  understanding  providing  for  the  payment  of  interest 
on Government cash balances being held in the TSA with Bank Indonesia. The next-day daily 
sweep  of  the  Government's  revenue  accounts  in  all  commercial  banks  into  the  TSA  was 
completed  this  year.  The  MOF  decree  No.  116/2009,  issued  in  June  2009,  states  that  by 
January 2010 all revenue accounts maintained in collecting bank branches will be swept to the 
TSA by the  end of the same day. The staged implementation of the same-day daily sweep of 
revenue  accounts  into  the  TSA  started  on  1  July  2009  in  the  western  region.  This  reform, 
coupled  with  the  agreement  between  MOF  and  Bank  Indonesia  on  payment  of  interest  on 
Government  cash  balances  held  in  the  TSA,  should  enable  the  Treasury  to  optimize  on  cash 
balances, including the investment of surplus cash. 
 
77. 
The consolidation of funds into TSA also helps in cash forecasting and thus in relieving 
the  year-end  bunching  of  expenditures.  The  next  DPL  program  will  support  the  issuance  of  a 
new  MOF  regulation  on  cash  forecasting,  which  will  also  set  the  stage  for  subsequently 
improving  cash  forecasting  at  the  provincial  treasury  offices  (KPPNs)  and  budget  forecasting 
capabilities in some 22,000 satkers (spending units).

78.  MOF  is  in  the  process  of  implementing  an  integrated  financial  management  system  to 
streamline the multitude of financial data processing applications currently used by government 
institutions  and  to  enhance  budget  execution.  The  contract  for  SPAN  was  signed  on  10  July 
2009. It is projected to become operational in selected pilot offices of the treasury beginning in 
2011 and then rolled out to all KPPNs and pilot line ministries in 2012. It is also expected that 
the  Directorate  General  for  Treasury  will  have  identified  and  completed  improvements  in  the 
business processes of participating institutions in 2010, and that a final version of the chart of 
accounts will be available and integrated into the SPAN.  
 
SPAN  will  provide  the  backbone  for  modernized  treasury  operations  with  modules 
79. 
related to all aspects of the budget execution process. A number of deficiencies that currently 
exist  in  the  budget  execution  process—fragmented  data,  inaccurate  and  delayed  reporting  of 
both revenue and expenditure transactions, and lack of information on program execution—will 
be  mitigated  with  the  automation  of  business  processes.  The  establishment  of  an  integrated 
financial  database  will  provide  the  ability  to  capture  transactions  at  every  stage  of  the  budget 
execution process.

Progress on streamlining the regulatory framework for public procurement is underway, 
80. 
though  not  at  the  pace  anticipated.  LKPP  (National  Public  Procurement  Agency)  is  currently 
working  on  two  tracks—the  preparation  of  a  new  procurement  law  and  revision  of  the 
Presidential Decree 80/2003. It has initiated background studies for a draft procurement law and 
expects to have the studies as well as a first draft of the legal text of the new procurement law 
prepared  by  September  2010.  However,  the  enactment  of  a  new  procurement  law  could  be  a 
lengthy  process,  as  it  will  require  significant  consultation  and  consensus  building  with 
stakeholders,  and  will  possibly  face  opposition  from  interest  groups.  In  the  interim,  LKPP  is 
working to revise Presidential Decree 80/2003 with the intention of mandating a set of standard 
bidding  documents  to  be  used  by  all  agencies.16  Presidential  Decree  80/2003  promotes  the 
basic  principles  of  procurement:  transparency,  open  and  fair  competition,  economy,  and 
efficiency. It covers all areas of procurement that use public funds and contracting entities at all 
levels of Government.

with final issuance scheduled for January 2010. Harmonizing Presidential Decree 80/2003 and

3. 

Core Policy Area III: Improved Delivery of Public Services 

83. 
Beyond allocating more resources to poverty alleviation programs, several initiatives are 
being pursued to enhance the effectiveness of these programs. These include improvements in 
the  targeting  of  poverty  alleviation  programs  to  ensure  that  they  reach  the  appropriate 
beneficiaries.  DPSP-5  will  support  the  Government’s  reform  objectives  in  terms  of  enhancing 
the pro-poor impact of public expenditures by increasing funding for poverty programs. 
 

a. 

Trigger 11: Continue to use poverty targeting in determining the size of 
the subdistrict community block grants under PNPM and increase the 
average size of the block grant for the poorest subdistricts. (current 
status: achieved) 

 
84. 
The  National  Community  Empowerment  Program  (PNPM  Mandiri)—a  program  of 
community block grants that is the Government’s flagship anti-poverty program—is being scaled 
up in terms of geographical coverage.17 The size of the average block grant is being increased 
at  the  same  time.  By  the  end  of  2009,  the  program  will  reach  every  subdistrict  (kecamatan) 
across  Indonesia  (6,400  subdistricts,  of  which  about  4,500  are  located  in  rural  areas)  and  full 
coverage throughout the country will be maintained in 2010. Central Government funding for the 
entire  PNPM  program  is  planned  to  increase  by  23%,  from  Rp10.3  trillion  in  2009  to  an 
estimated  Rp12.7  trillion  in  2010.  The  Government  has  also  introduced  poverty  targeting  to 
determine  the  size  of  community  block  grants,  so  that  the  increased  funds  are  allocated  to 
intended  beneficiaries.  The  average  size  of  the  block  grant  for  the  2,000  poorest  subdistricts 
was increased to Rp2.6 billion in 2009, from Rp1.8 billion in 2008. 
 
85. 
A  unified  household  targeting  database  is  necessary  to  effectively  target  poverty 
programs.  Many  Government  poverty  alleviation  programs,  such  as  the  unconditional  and 
conditional  cash  transfer  programs,  the  rice  subsidy  program,  and  the  health  insurance 
program, are directed to households. However, they are currently implemented by different line 
ministries, each using an independent database of beneficiaries. To improve the effectiveness 
and  coordination  of  poverty  programs,  and  reduce  duplication  of  efforts  in  data  collection,  the 
Government  intends  to  improve  the  accuracy  of  information  on  poor  households  and  move 
toward  the  use  of  a  single  database.  The  DPL  program  will  support  the  establishment  of  a 
unified household targeting database and the institutional mechanisms to update the database, 
expected to be completed in 2010.

C. 

Some Key Reforms in DPL/DPSP Core Areas Not Included in the Policy Matrix 

86. 
Indonesia’s  progress  in  the  core  policy  areas  that  the  DPL/DPSP  supports  were 
complemented  by  actions  not  included  in  the  DPL/DPSP  policy  matrix.  These  include  policies 
under the PESF to bolster market and investor confidence following the global financial turmoil 
in late 2008, passage of a new Public Service Law, and passage of a regional taxes bill.  
 
87. 
Under the PESF, several measures were initiated to (i) reassure financial markets and 
maintain financial system stability by enhancing the financial safety net, maintaining the stability 
of the banking system, and ensuring predictability in the Government’s financing requirements 
for 2009 and 2010; (ii) sustain critical public expenditures while maintaining budget discipline to 
mitigate  the  poverty  impacts  of  the  growth  slowdown;  and  (iii)  draw  in  private  investment  and 
support  exports  by  revising  the  Presidential  Regulation  on  the  DNI,  improving  transparency  in 
revenues  from  extractive  industries  through  the  Extractive  Industries  Transparency  Initiative, 
and enhancing access to trade finance.  
 
The new Public Service Law, passed by Parliament on 23 June 2009, provides a clear 
88. 
blueprint  for  the  new  administration  to  pursue  civil  service  reform.  The  law  (i)  defines  public 
services  and  public  service  providers;  (ii)  requires  periodic  reporting  on  public  service 
performance;  (iii)  authorizes  the  merger  of  different  Government  entities  for  the  purpose  of 
increasing the efficiency and effectiveness of services; (iv) sets forth the rights and obligations 
of  civil  servants;  (v)  obliges  all  institutions  providing  public  services  to  set  clear  service 
standards;  and  (vi)  establishes  principles  for  handling  complaints  as  well  as  meaningful 
sanctions  for  nonperformance  or  wrongdoing.  All  rules  and  regulations  pertaining  to  public 
service provision are required to comply with the stipulations of the new law within 2 years of its 
passage. 

89. 
Parliament passed a regional taxes bill in August 2009, to be fully implemented by 2011. 
The bill, which had been under deliberation since 2006, specifies a closed list of 41 taxes and 
levies  within  ranges  that  provincial  and  district  authorities  are  allowed  to  impose.  The 
introduction of a closed-list mechanism in the bill will prevent regions from introducing taxes or 
levies not included in the list, thus lending a degree of certainty to investors.

reforms;  further  improve  the  results  orientation  of  the  budget  and  its  execution;  continue  to

E. 

Financing Plan 

92. 
The  Government  has  requested  a  loan  of  $200  million  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital 
resources  for  DPSP-5.  DPSP-5  provides  parallel  cofinancing  for  the  World  Bank-supported 
DPL-6,  for  which  the  Government  has  requested  $750  million.  In  addition,  the  Government 
intends  to  request  $100  million  from  the  Government  of  Japan  for  parallel  cofinancing  of  the 
DPL-6. The DPSP loan will have a 15-year term, including a grace period of 3 years; an interest 
rate determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending 
facility; a commitment charge of 0.15% per annum; conversion options that may be exercised in 
accordance  with  the  draft  Loan  Agreement,  the  loan  regulations,  and  ADB’s  conversion 
guidelines;  and  such  other  terms  and  conditions  as  set  forth  in  the  draft  program  Loan 
Agreement.  The  Government  has  made  its  own  independent  decision  to  borrow  under  ADB’s 
LIBOR-based lending facility, and it has given an undertaking that this choice was not made on 
the basis of any advice from ADB. Responding favorably to the Government’s request will signal 
ADB’s relevance in an emerging, confident, and well-performing middle-income country.  
 

 

  24

domestic  and  foreign  debt  principal  repayment.  ADB’s  proposed  support  is  based  on  the 
strengths of the policy package, its development impact, the importance of the sectors covered, 
and investment needs.

3. 

Procurement and Disbursement Arrangements  

96. 
The  program  loan  of  $200  million  will  be  released  in  a  single  tranche  upon  loan 
effectiveness.  The  loan  proceeds  will  be  used  to  finance  the  full  foreign  exchange  costs 
(excluding  local  duties  and  taxes)  of  items  produced  and  procured  in  ADB  member  countries, 
excluding  the  items  specified  in  the  negative  list  of  ineligible  items  (Appendix  7)  and  imports 
financed  by  other  bilateral  and  multilateral  sources.  In  accordance  with  ADB  provisions  for 
simplifying disbursement of program loans,18 the proceeds of the program loan will be disbursed 
to  the  Republic  of  Indonesia  as  the  Borrower.  No  supporting  import  documentation  will  be 
required  if  during  each  year  that  loan  proceeds  are  expected  to  be  disbursed  the  value  of 
Indonesia’s  total  imports  minus  imports  from  nonmember  countries,  ineligible  imports,  and 
imports  financed  under  other  official  development  assistance  is  equal  to  or  greater  than  the 
amount of the loan expected to be disbursed during such year. The Government will certify its

compliance  with  this  formula  with  each  withdrawal  request.  Otherwise,  import  documentation
