4. 

Anticorruption  

97. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the Government. Consistent with its commitment to good governance, accountability, and 
transparency, ADB reserves the right to investigate, directly or through its agents, any alleged 
corrupt,  fraudulent,  collusive,  or  coercive  practices  relating  to  the  Program.  To  support  these 
efforts,  relevant  provisions  of  ADB’s  Anticorruption  Policy  are  included  in  the  loan  regulations 
and  the  bidding  documents  for  the  Program.  In  particular,  all  contracts  financed  by  ADB  in 
connection  with  the  Program  shall  include  provisions  specifying  the  right  of  ADB  to  audit  and 
examine  the  records  and  accounts  of  the  Executing  Agency  and  all  contractors,  suppliers, 
consultants, and other service providers as they relate to the Program. In addition, DPSP-5 has 
a  core  focus  on  improving  governance  and  anticorruption.  It  promotes  transparency  in  PFM. 
Noteworthy  progress  has  been  achieved  through  the  TSA  system,  which  will  help  the 
Government  in  its  anticorruption  efforts.  The  Program’s  focus  on  tax  audit  procedures, 
simplifying and/or eliminating unnecessary business licenses, and implementing good corporate 
governance in state-owned banks will also further the Government’s anticorruption agenda and 
improve the investment climate. 
 
98. 
The Government places significant emphasis on strengthening internal control systems 
and  overall  PFM,  with  support  from  the  World  Bank  through  the  Government  Financial 
Management  and  Revenue  Administration  Project  and  from  ADB  through  the  State  Audit 
Reform  Sector  Development  Program.19  Reforms  and  capacity  development 
initiatives 
supported under both of these programs have led to initial progress in strengthening PFM. 

5. 

Accounting, Auditing, and Reporting 

99. 
ADB retains the right to audit the use of loan proceeds and to verify the accuracy of the 
Government’s  certification  for  the  withdrawal  applications.  Before  withdrawal,  the  Government 
will nominate a deposit account at Bank Indonesia to receive all loan proceeds. The account will 
be managed, operated, and liquidated in accordance with terms satisfactory to ADB.  

6. 

Performance Monitoring, Evaluation, and Program Review 

100.  The CMEA, MOF, and BAPPENAS will continuously monitor implementation of the DPL-
related reforms and their impacts, in line with the overall program framework and outcome and 
output indicators agreed upon with the Government. Participating development partners will also 
evaluate the triggers based on frequent discussions with key government counterparts, and on 
evidence in the form of key implementation decrees, circulars, etc.

improvements in (a) the investment climate, (b) public financial management and 
governance, and (c) service delivery to the poor; 
raising the profile of key issues at the ministerial level, accelerating the timetable 
for  policy  actions  to  be  taken,  addressing  administrative  and  bureaucratic 
bottlenecks to reform, and encouraging policy coordination across economic and 
line ministries; 
sustained  ADB  engagement  in  policy  dialogue  with  the  Government  on  the 
direction  and  content  of,  and  strategies  for,  its  economic,  structural,  and

consistency in sectors where ADB has been actively involved); 
aid  harmonization  and  cofinancing  by  the  key  development  partners  (ADB,  the

and dialogue,  
facilitation,  through  crosscutting  reforms,  of  sector-specific  reforms  in  areas 
where ADB is providing or is planning future support. 

 
102. 
Institutional. Significant benefits stem from the engagement of Indonesia’s three main 
development partners, which collectively provide an estimated 80% of official external support. 
Participation  in  the  DPL  series  has  contributed  to  effective  institutional  coordination  among 
development partners as well as between the Government and these partners (Appendix 6). In 
some  of  the  core  areas,  such  as  public  financial  management  and  poverty  alleviation,  the 
coordination process is formalized through multi-donor facilities (such as the PFM Multi-Donor 
Trust Fund and the PNPM  Support Facility), chaired by the Government and managed by the 
World  Bank.  This  has  helped  streamline  and  coordinate  the  provision  of  advisory  support 
through  TA  to  best  meet  the  Government’s  needs.  The  measures  supported  under  the 
DPL/DPSP series will result in sustained improvements in institutional capacity in key areas of 
policy formulation such as fiscal policy, debt and treasury management, and public expenditure 
and financial management. 
 
103.  Social.  The  main  contributions  of  the  DPSP  series  in  this  area  is  to  improve  public 
administration, reorient public expenditures toward productive needs, and continuously support 
government  measures  to  align  its  resources  effectively  with  its  medium-term  objectives  of 
economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction.  By  supporting  strategic  reforms  aimed  at  improving 
public service delivery, the Program will have a direct and beneficial social impact. Appendix 9 
presents a summary poverty reduction and social strategy. 
 
104.  Economic.  The  nature  of  the  DPSP  series  limits  the  scope  for  quantitative  economic 
analysis.  In  qualitative  terms,  the  Program's  main  impacts  will  be  lower  business  transaction 
costs, 
for  MSMEs),  and  progressive 
improvements  in  both  the  quantity  and  quality  of  public  services  (including  better  targeting  of 
such  services  to  the  poor).  It  is  expected  that  the  lower  business  transaction  costs  from 
regulatory  reform,  and  reduced  times  for  business  licensing,  VAT  refunds,  and  import  and 
export  applications  through  the  NSW,  will  lead  to  greater  competition  and  encourage  more 
productive investments. These benefits will help foster economic growth and reduce poverty in 
the  medium  term.  The  net  effect  of  improved  access  to  finance  for  MSMEs  will  be  to  reduce 
poverty  indirectly  by  fostering  additional  growth.  Initially,  the  main  beneficiaries  would  be 
MSMEs, with benefits eventually filtering to the wider population through increased employment 
generation.

106.  Resettlement,  indigenous  people,  and  environment.  Implementation  of  the  DPSP-5 
measures will cause no direct or indirect involuntary resettlement, nor will it lead to any issues 
affecting indigenous peoples. The measures supported under DPSP-5 are unlikely to have any 
adverse environmental impacts. 

B. 

Risks and Mitigating Measures 

Implementation of DPSP-5 is subject to the following risks: 

External  vulnerabilities.  Indonesia  has  weathered  the  global  economic  crisis 
well,  reflecting  its  increased  resilience  to  external  shocks built  up  over  previous 
years.  Factors  limiting  the  potential  impacts  of  external  shocks  include  diversity 
of  exports,  moderate  public  debt,  limited  external  debt  exposure,  and  an 
adequate  level  of  reserves.  The  banking  sector  is  also  now  sufficiently  strong. 
The  maintenance  of  a  financial  sector  safety  net  supported  by  PESF  and 
DPL/DPSP will further improve the resilience of the banking sector.  

Nevertheless,  risks  remain  high,  especially  during  a  period  of  global  financial 
turmoil. Indonesia has an open financial system. Domestic residents can switch 
to  foreign  assets  easily  and  foreign  holdings  are  significant,  especially  in  the 
stock market and government bonds. The country is thus vulnerable to shifts in 
investor  sentiment.  If  significant  funds  are  pulled  back  because  of  liquidity 
demands in other countries and/or increased emerging market risk aversion, this 
could  increase  pressure  on  domestic  interest  and  exchange  rates.  In  addition, 
the  Government  has  large  gross  financing  needs  over  the  next  few  years,  and 
tighter  credit  markets  and  increased  risk  aversion  could  limit  the  Government’s 
ability to tap international financial markets. This could force the Government to 
cut budgetary outlays to maintain fiscal balance, with adverse consequences for 
infrastructure and social expenditures. It could also distract the Government from 
implementing its medium-term reform agenda, including those supported by the 
DPL/DPSP. 
 
The measures taken since mid-2008 to mitigate the effects of the global financial 
crisis,  including  the  bilateral  swap  arrangements  with  the  People's  Republic  of 
China and Japan and support from the PESF, will help reduce this risk. But it will 
also  require  close  cooperation  between  Bank  Indonesia  and  the  economic 
ministries to reassure bondholders that their investments are safe (from inflation 
and exchange rate movements) while drawing in private investment through the 
kinds of structural reforms supported by the DPL/DPSP.

Subsidies. As international oil prices have fallen since mid-2008, domestic fuel 
subsides  have  also  declined.  The  proposed  budget  for  2010  envisages  energy 
subsidies of 1.6% of GDP, down from 1.9% of GDP in 2009 and a recent peak of 
4.5%  of  GDP  in  2008.  However,  the  recent  increase  in  international  fuel  prices 
suggests  that  a  return  to  high  international  fuel  prices  remains  a  risk.  Fixed 
domestic  fuel  prices  and  the  subsidies  they  create  represent  a  threat  to  fiscal 
sustainability  in  the  longer  term.  They  are  also  regressive  and  inefficient,  and 
have high opportunity costs. The Government has shown its willingness to raise 
domestic  prices  and  reduce  subsidies,  most  recently  in  May  2008.  ADB  will 
continue to engage the Government in this area through policy dialogue.  

Fiduciary constraints. Utilization of public resources continues to be a concern, 
notwithstanding the improvements underway. The overall fiduciary assessments 
undertaken  since  the  2001  country  financial  accountability  assessment  point  to 
considerable  improvements  in  Indonesia's  fiduciary  environment.  Ongoing 
programs  supported  by  several  development  partners  provide  significant  TA  to 
strengthen fiduciary governance. The DPL/DPSP focus on strengthening budget 
preparation,  execution,  and 
financial  management  will

The  Government  and  law  enforcement  authorities  have  taken  a  range  of 
measures aimed at bolstering public and investor confidence.

109. 
I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and,  acting  in  the  absence  of  the  President,  under  the 
provisions  of  Article  35.1  of  the  Articles  of  Agreement  of  ADB,  I  recommend  that  the  Board 
approve the loan of $200,000,000 to the Republic of Indonesia for the Fifth Development Policy 
Support  Program  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources,  with  interest  to  be  determined  in 
accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; a term of 
15  years,  including  a  grace  period  of  3  years;  and  such  other  terms  and  conditions  as  are 
substantially  in  accordance  with  those  set  forth  in  the  draft  Loan  Agreement  presented  to  the 
Board.

RESULTS ACHIEVED UNDER THE DEVELOPMENT POLICY LOAN/ 
DEVELOPMENT POLICY SUPPORT PROGRAM 

Core Policy Area 1: Macroeconomic Stability 

A. 
 
1. 
The  DPL/DPSP  series  in  2004–2006  sought  to  improve  debt  management  and  fiscal 
policy  management  by  reducing  subsidies  to  the  nonpoor  and  making  revenue  administration 
more efficient through the expansion of modern tax officers. 
 
2. 
Overall  macroeconomic  fundamentals  remain  sound  and  fiscal  consolidation  has 
improved with the expansion of the tax base and improved efficiency of tax administration. From 
2004–2008, economic growth averaged a substantive 5.7%, the public debt-to-gross domestic 
product  (GDP)  ratio  declined  nearly  28  percentage  points  to  a  moderate  33%,  budget  deficits 
were manageable, and international reserves remained adequate to provide the country with a 
comfortable  liquidity  cushion.  Increasing  non-oil  and  gas  revenues  as  a  percentage  of  GDP 
were supported by a prior DPL/DPSP action to expand modernization of tax offices and the tax 
base  to  include  medium  and  small  taxpayers.  Additional  reforms  to  improve  tax  analysis, 
including the creation of a Tax Policy Office, are expected to generate improvements in revenue 
collection.  
 
On the expenditure side, reductions in untargeted fuel subsidies in 2005 allowed greater 
3. 
social spending, but untargeted subsidies remain burdensome. In 2005, the Government raised 
fuel prices, resulting in the decline of fuel subsidies from 4% of GDP in 2004 to 2.8% in 2006, 
freeing up $10 billion a year. This amount was rolled out into cash transfers targeted at the poor, 
or went toward higher health and education expenditures. However, as oil prices continued to 
break records throughout 2008, fuel subsidies rose sharply, causing the Government to spend 
an  additional  Rp50  trillion  (1.2%  of  GDP)  in  the  first  part  of  the  year.  In  May 2008,  the 
Government  again  increased  fuel  prices  by  almost  30%  and  accompanied  this  with  a  widely 
publicized  and  improved  cash  transfer  program.  This  move,  together  with  a  reduction  in  oil 
prices in the second half of 2008, limited the energy subsidy in 2008 to 4.5% of GDP. 

 
4. 
Rating  agencies  have  responded  favorably  to  Indonesia’s  lower  debt  ratio  and  the 
reform packages. In a reflection of the country’s more sound economic footing, all three credit 
agencies have raised their credit ratings at least three notches since 2003. Standard and Poor’s 
upgraded Indonesia’s credit rating from CCC+ in 2003 to BB– by 2008; likewise in this period, 
Moody’s raised its ratings from B2 to Ba3; and Fitch raised its from B to BB. In supporting their 
ratings  upgrades,  the  agencies  cited  debt  reduction  as  the  primary  cause,  as  well  as  the 
Government’s  commitment  to  broad-based  reform,  including  changes  to  investment  laws, 
customs  and  tax  reforms,  and  fiscal  reforms,  specifically  in  treasury  and  budget—measures 
supported by the DPL/DPSP series. 
 
B. 
 
5. 
The  DPL/DPSP  series  seeks  to  improve  the  investment  climate  through  several  key 
entry  areas,  including  regulatory  reform,  tax  reform,  custom  and  trade  reform,  financial  sector 
stability, and improved access to finance by small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). 
 
6. 
In  2006,  the  Government  issued  three  economic  policy  packages  covering  investment 
climate,  infrastructure,  and  financial  reform.  In  2007,  a  comprehensive  follow-up  package  was 
issued  detailing  168  specific  reform  measures  to  be  carried  out.  As  a  result,  business 
perceptions have improved. A study of manufacturing firms in mid-2007 indicated improvements 

Core Policy Area 2: Investment Climate 

 

 42  

Appendix 3 

licenses  and  multiple 

in  VAT  refunds,  tax  filing  processes,  informal  payments,  and  faster  import  and  custom 
clearance. Surveys of foreign investors also show that perceptions of Indonesia are improving. 
In  the  annual  Japan  Bank  of  International  Cooperation  survey,  620  Japanese  multinational 
companies, operating in global markets, ranked Indonesia the eighth most promising country for 
overseas business in 2008, similar to its rank in the previous year. Although full implementation 
of  the  investment  policy  packages  has  yet  to  take  place,  initial  signs  are  encouraging—
investment rates have risen from less than 20% of GDP in 2003 to 27.6% in 2008. 
 
Regulatory  reforms  supported  by  the  DPL/DPSP  process,  particularly  those  relating  to 
7. 
simplifying  and  eliminating  unnecessary  business 
registration 
requirements,  have  led  to  more  streamlined  procedures  supportive  of  the  investment  climate. 
According  to  Doing  Business  2010,  the  time  to  set  up  a  business  has  fallen  significantly  from 
168 days in 2003, to 105 days in 2007, to 60 days in 2009.1 Another key achievement has been 
the  passage  of  the  Investment  Law,  which  clarified  previously  arbitrary  investment  rules.  The 
law  focuses  on  equal  treatment  of  foreign  and  domestic  investment,  removes  the  forced 
divestment and limited duration of foreign investment in the old law, lengthens the time horizon 
to hold land, liberalizes some immigration procedures, and allows for international arbitration. 
 
8. 
Tax  reform  has  addressed  some  of  the  key  complaints  from  the  business  community. 
Reforms  in  tax  administration  have  halved  the  time  for  VAT  refunds;  in  addition,  more  than 
Rp10 trillion (roughly $1 billion) in outstanding VAT refunds have been settled. New procedures 
have  been  put  in  place  to  issue  VAT  refunds  to  export  companies  within  set  time  frames. 
Standard  operating  procedures  for  a  complaint  management  system  have  been  issued.  The 
DPL/DPSP  has  also  supported  the  issuance  of  a  decree  on  tax  audit  procedures  that  allows 
taxpayers to delay payment of tax assessments from disputed audits. However, this decree only 
affects disputes arising since the 2008 tax year; older disputes continue to be arbitrated under 
the old rule. 
 
Significant  progress  on  trade  and  customs  reform  has  been  made,  with  pilot  testing  of 
9. 
Indonesia’s  national  single  window  (NSW)  and  paperless  import  clearance.  Implementation  of 
the  NSW  is  one  of  the  country’s  most  important  trade  facilitation  initiatives.  Under  a  single 
window,  exporters  and  importers  will  no  longer  be  required  to  apply  individually  to  multiple 
agencies—significantly reducing the number of days it takes to export and import goods. A pilot 
project is underway in Jakarta’s main port and will be expanded to other ports in preparation for 
the establishment of an ASEAN single window. Other trade reforms sought by the DPL aimed to 
improve  the  technical  capacity  of  the  tariff  team  in  setting  and  evaluating  tariff  changes  and 
nontariff barriers imposed by line ministries. 
 
10. 
An original objective of the DPL/DPSP series was to strengthen the financial sector by 
reducing the role of state-owned banks and increasing the share of financial assets at nonbank 
financial  institutions.  As  of  June  2008,  the  share  of  state-owned  banks  in  the  banking  system 
(36%) was a significant 10 percentage points less than in 2003, indicating that the role of private 
banks  in  the  sector  is  increasing.  Less  progress  has  been  made  with  nonbank  financial 
institutions—they accounted for 19.9% of total assets in the financial sector as of March 2008, 
compared with a 17.4% share in 2005. However, other indicators point to a healthier financial 
system—profitability  ratios  such  as  net  interest  margin,  return  on  assets,  and  return  on  equity 
remain  strong.  Nonperforming  loans,  particularly  in  state-owned  banks,  have  declined 
substantially  after  peaking  in  2005.  In  terms  of  diversification,  SME  lending  has  been  rising 
rapidly and now accounts for half of the lending portfolio.

Core Policy Area 3: Public Financial Management and Governance 

In  strengthening  the  stability  of  the  financial  sector,  the  DPL/DPSP  has  supported  the 
11. 
implementation  of  a  sounder  financial  safety  net.  At  the  start  of  the  DPL  series,  there  was  a 
need  to  reduce  the  economic  distortion  and  potential  moral  hazard  caused  by  the  blanket 
guarantee  that  existed  at  the  time,  which  had  been  introduced  during  the  Asian  crisis  1997–
1998  to  stem  bank  runs.  To  this  effect,  the  DPL/DPSP  series  supported  several  reforms, 
including a deposit insurance scheme, institutionalizing Bank Indonesia’s role as lender of last 
resort,  and  establishing  institutional  processes  and  mechanisms  for  resolving  troubled  banks. 
By  the  end  of  the  DPL-4/DPSP-3  in  2007,  coverage  on  deposits  had  been  reduced  from  a 
blanket guarantee in 2003 to Rp100 million. Indonesia is one of the few countries in the world 
that  removed  its  blanket  guarantee  on  schedule.  In  October  2008  the  authorities  announced 
several  confidence-building  measures  in  response  to  the  global  financial  crisis,  including  a 
twenty-fold increase in the deposit guarantee to Rp2 billion (approximately $200,000).  
 
C. 
 
12. 
To  improve  the  efficiency,  transparency,  and  accountability  of  public  finances,  the 
DPL/DPSP  series  has  focused  on  three  key  areas  of  reform:  (i)  modernizing  public  financial 
management  systems,  (ii)  strengthening  institutional  reform  within  the  Ministry  of  Finance 
(MOF), and more recently (iii) civil service reform.  
 
Changes in the legal and regulatory architecture for PFM are now largely complete and 
13. 
the  focus  has  moved  toward  implementing  a  modern  PFM  system.  Before  the  start  of  the 
DPL/DPSP  series,  the  Government’s  financial  operations  were  based  on  outdated  laws  (from 
1925)  that  had  been  updated  with  a  series  of  inadequate  decrees.  The  previous  PFM  system 
allowed for systematic and pervasive corruption, collusion, and nepotism because assignments 
were  unclear,  transparency  was  low,  and  enforcement  poor.  Budget  formulation  was  opaque 
and inefficient, making it difficult to quantify basic concepts of the budget. Budget execution was 
often delayed and monitoring arrangements were weak. Procurement processes were prone to 
corruption  and  collusion.  Accounting  and  reporting  were  fragmented  and  not  always  reliable, 
and mandates of government audit bodies were not clearly defined. The DPL supported various 
measures in the areas of budget preparation and execution to create the regulatory framework 
for a more modern PFM system.  
 
14. 
A key achievement under the DPL/DPSP series has been the implementation of the TSA 
to  improve  cash  management  of  public  finances.  At  the  start  of  the  DPL  series,  more  than 
18,000  commercial  bank  accounts—and  other  accounts  not  even  known  to  the  Treasury—
handled  government  funds.  As  an  initial  step,  DPL-1  addressed  regulatory  deficiencies  in  the 
PFM  system,  including  the  passage  of  several  laws  defining  the  regulatory  framework. 
Reorganization of MOF was also carried out to begin the process of establishing a TSA, and to 
clean  up  the  Government’s  cash  management  issues.  DPL-2/DPSP-1  then  supported 
regulations  underlining  these  laws  and  adopted  an  implementation  plan.  DPL-3/DPSP-2  pilot 
tested  the  TSA  to  have  zero-balance  accounts  in  more  than  50  provincial  treasury  offices 
(KPPNs).  DPL-4/DPSP-3  extended  the  TSA  coverage  to  nearly  full  implementation  on 
government  expenditure  accounts.  Progress  on  covering  revenue  accounts  was  more 
complicated, but has now advanced significantly. 
 
15. 
improved,  but  execution  remains  problematic.  The 
DPL/DPSP series has helped move forward reforms to reengineer business processes across 
the  budget  cycle.  The  national  budget  is  now  compatible  with  the  international  standard  GFS 
classification.  Fiscal  reporting  is  more  comprehensive  and  timely.  Elements  of  a  medium-term 
expenditure framework have been introduced, although they are not yet fully operational in the 

Budgeting  procedures  have

in  2006-2007  supported  comprehensive  reform  of 

budget system. Whereas the planning and reporting side of the budget process has improved, 
executing the budget has remained weak, with about 50% of capital expenditures being spent in 
the last quarter. 
 
Procurement  reform  has  been  slow  to  take  off.  The  original  trigger  aimed  only  at 
16. 
strengthening the existing National Procurement Office. Instead, the Government established a 
new National Public Procurement Agency (LKPP) as an independent office directly responsible 
to  the  President.  As  an  independent  agency  with  adequate  resources,  authority,  and  strong 
political  backing,  it  will  be  in  a  stronger  position  to  drive  public  procurement  reform.  However, 
because  of  the  time  required  to  set  up  the  LKPP,  there  was  a  lack  of  progress  on  other 
procurement reforms, such as developing a comprehensive national public sector procurement 
law. This law is needed to address the numerous inconsistencies resulting from decentralization 
reforms,  which  have  enabled  authorities  at  various  levels  of  government  to  issue  their  own 
procurement procedures. Other deficiencies of the system include slow progress in the passage 
of  regulations,  and  the  adoption  of  standard  tools  such  as  bidding  documents  and  user 
manuals. 
 
17. 
Initial  steps to  address civil  service  reform  have  been  launched.  Lack of  administrative 
capacity  and  distorted  incentives  in  government  bureaucracy  have  constrained  both  policy 
implementation and delivery of public services. As  an initial step to reforming the civil service, 
the  structure  and 
the  DPL/DPSP 
remuneration framework for high-ranking state officials. A task force was set up to examine the 
entire  compensation  package  with  the  goal  of  creating  a  more  transparent,  systematic,  and 
coherent framework for pay and allowances based on a comprehensive job evaluation and pay 
grading.  Building  on  this,  MOF  has  developed  a  comprehensive  civil  service  reform  plan  and 
action plan for itself, which is now being pilot-tested in other agencies.  
 
D. 
 
18. 
The  groundwork  for  improving  poverty  targeting  of  basic  services  has  been  initiated. 
Before the rise in fuel prices in 2005, Indonesia’s social protection system was characterized by 
emergency  short-term  safety  net  programs  and  price  subsidies.  The  country’s  three  targeted 
programs  accounted  for  less  than  0.5%  of  GDP,  compared  with  almost  4.0%  of  GDP  for  the 
untargeted fuel subsides, of which less than 0.2% of GDP went to the poorest quintile. As the 
fuel  price  hike  freed  up  more  funds  for  social  spending,  the  DPL  supported  capacity  building 
initiatives  to  improve  the  targeting  of  these  released  funds.  The  2005  fuel  hike  was 
accompanied  by  a  new  cash  transfer  program  to  help  alleviate  the  impact  on  the  poorest 
households—representing a substantial shift from the ineffective and inefficient general subsidy 
program. Evaluative assessments were conducted to improve targeting and performance of the 
cash transfer program, and the lessons were incorporated into the new cash transfer program 
that  accompanied  the  May  2008  fuel  price  increase.  The  Government  has  moved  to  set  up  a 
comprehensive  monitoring  and  evaluation  function,  including  the  establishment  of  a  unit  to 
undertake  performance  evaluations,  with  the  findings  to  be  used  as  an  input  to  the 
Government’s planning and budgeting cycle.

Achieved. The Presidential Regulation was issued on 23 June 2009. The regulation allows ministries and 
central  Government  agencies  to  turn  over  or  delegate  their  authority  to  issue  business  licenses  to  the 
National  Investment  Coordinating  Board  (BKPM).  It  authorizes  BKPM  to  establish  a  one-stop  shop  for 
investment  licensing  as  well  as  an  electronic  information  and  licensing  service.  At  the  local  government 
level as well, the regulation requires that business licensing authority be transferred to local one-stop shops, 
and empowers BKPM to monitor the implementation and performance of the local one-stop shops. 

Satisfactory. The decision on the operational model and the governance structure for the Indonesia NSW 
was  originally  scheduled  for  December  2008  and  then  moved  forward  to  mid-2009.  However,  following 
delays  in  the  technical  experts'  recommendations  for  an  operational  model,  it  is  now  anticipated  that  the 
decision will be made at the end of 2009. The Indonesia NSW team submitted a draft proposal with options 
and recommendations to the Coordinating Minister for Economic Affairs in August 2009. 
 
 
Achieved.  The  issuance  in  December  2008  of  the  decree  allowing  recognition  of  digital  signatures  for 
individual  taxpayer  registration  and  for  filing  personal  income  tax  returns  has  permitted  the  roll  out  of  e-
registration and e-filing for taxpayers. Subsequently, the Directorate General (Tax) issued a new regulation 
(no. 24/PJ/2009) to enable electronic tax registration. The regulation specifies the procedures for electronic 
registration with a taxpayer identification number and/or VAT collector number. The electronic filing instead 
of paper filing will reduce taxpayer burden and filing costs. 
 
Achieved. The Directorate General (Tax) decree was issued in July 2009. It will implement new simplified 
standard format capturing key financial indicators and annual tax returns, from all types of businesses. It will 
do  away  with  the  need  to  physically  deliver  financial  statements  to  tax  offices,  enabling  completely  online 
submission of tax documents.

DEVELOPMENT COORDINATION  

Major Development Partners 

Institutional Arrangements and Processes for Development Coordination 

A. 
 
The  DPL/DPSP  series  is  a  partnership  between  the  Government  of  Indonesia,  the 
1. 
Government  of  Japan,  the  World  Bank  and  ADB.    ADB  began  participating  in  the  series  in 
2005,1 contributing $200 million annually for a total of $800 million through 31 December 2008.  
The  Government  of  Japan's  contribution  was  $100  million  annually  during  2004–2006  and  in 
2008, and $200 million in 2007. The World Bank's contribution rose from $300 million for DPL-1 
in 2004 to $750 million for DPL-5 and DPL-6 in 2008 and 2009 respectively, for a total of $3,400 
million. 
 
A number of bilateral and multilateral agencies provide technical assistance in the core 
2. 
areas  of  the  DPL/DPSP.    Table  A6  presents  some  key  programs  of  development  partners  in 
these core areas. 
 
B.  
 
3. 
Since the dissolution of the Consultative Group for Indonesia process in 2007, there has 
not  been  a  regular  development  partners'  forum  although  BAPPENAS  has  maintained 
responsibility for overall coordination among development partners.  Donor coordination is also 
supported  through  institutional  arrangements  under  key  Government  programs.  For  example, 
the DPL series has contributed to effective institutional coordination in key reform areas among 
development  partners  as  well  as  between  the  Government  and  these  partners.  In  public 
financial  management  and  improved  public  service  delivery  to  the  poor,  the  coordination 
process  is  also  formalized  through  multi-donor  facilities,  such  as  the  PFM  Multi-Donor  Trust 
Fund and the PNPM  Support Facility, chaired by the  Government and  managed by the World 
Bank.2  This  has  helped  streamline  and  coordinate  the  provision  of  advisory  support  through 
technical assistance (TA) to best meet the Government’s needs. 
 
C. 
 
Significant  benefits  stem  from  the  DPL/DPSP  partnership.  Policy  triggers  were  defined 
4. 
on  the  basis  of  mutual  trust  and  understanding  between  the  Government  and  the  three 
development partners, with a clear understanding of the direction of reforms, without excessive 
specificity that would create political difficulties or compromise the flexibility of the Government 
in overcoming obstacles to reform. This was especially important in areas where the Executing 
Agency, the Coordinating Ministry for Economic Affairs (CMEA), or the agencies working most 
closely  with  it—MOF  and  the  National  Development  Planning  Agency  (BAPPENAS)—had  no 
direct control over implementation of a particular reform, as other agencies or Parliament were 
involved.

FIDUCIARY ASSESSMENT 

Background and Analytical Underpinnings 

A. 
 
This note summarizes the current state of the public financial management system, maps 
1. 
the reform efforts being conducted, and provides an outlook with regards to overcoming current 
reform challenges, with a view to assessing fiduciary risks.  
 
Public  financial  management  (PFM)  reform,  as  previously  outlined  in  the  Government's 
2. 
White  Paper1,  continues  to  be  at  the  center  of  attention  of  Indonesian  policy  makers,  with  the 
global  economic  downturn  adding  further  urgency  to  the  agenda:  Indonesia  anticipates  a 
substantial  reduction  in  both  tax  revenues  and  foreign  exchange  reserves  resulting  from  the 
slowdown in the economy and sluggish trade. The exchange rate has weakened since last year, 
driving  up  the  cost  of  foreign  debt  servicing,  and  unemployment  is  high,  which  will  adversely 
impact the poverty rate.  
 
The crisis has fortunately been tempered by a decline in world oil prices. The decrease in 
3. 
oil prices has resulted in a reduction of oil subsidies, providing more fiscal space in the budget to 
counter the effects of the global economic downturn. Also, as a result of ongoing efforts among 
key  stakeholders,  well-sustained  reforms  have  mitigated  the  impact  of  this  downturn  on  the 
country’s  economy.  Nonetheless,  PFM  systems  in  the  country  now  face  unprecedented 
challenges to ensure efficient and effective budget allocations and disbursements, in line with the 
policy responses to the global and domestic economic turmoil.  
 
In  the  face  of  these  challenges,  the  commitment  of  key  stakeholders  in  the  budget 
4. 
process to vigorously pursuing the reform agenda remains unwavering and strong. The evolving 
agenda continues to be broad-based, comprising (i) improving results orientation in state budget 
planning  and  development,  (ii)  improving  budget  and  treasury  management,  (iii)  strengthening 
improving  public 
monitoring  and  evaluation  of  public  expenditures  and  programs,  (iv) 
procurement  systems,  and  (v)  improving  the  Government  accounting  and  audit  functions.  In 
summary,  the  agenda  is  designed  to  improve  how  revenues  are  raised  and  how  funds  are 
allocated,  used,  and  accounted  for—both  at  the  central  and  regional  levels.  PFM  improvement 
continues to be a key area of focus for DPL-6/DPSP-5, which will be a crucial instrument for the 
Government to flexibly, and in a self-determined fashion, underpin and flank its reform targets.  
 
5. 
The  following  assessment  draws  on  recent  economic  and  sector  work  undertaken  by 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB),  the  World  Bank,  and  other  development  partners.  A  public 
expenditure  and  financial  accountability  assessment  was  concluded  in  June  2008.  In  addition, 
this  assessment  has  taken  into  account  the  findings  of  a  joint  World  Bank–IMF  mission  on 
strengthening  budget  management  undertaken  in  June  2008,  the  results  of  a  previous  joint 
World Bank—IMF mission on budget reform priorities reported to the Government in June 2007, 
the  September  2008  update  of  the  Report  on  Observance  of  Standards  and  Codes  on  Fiscal 
Transparency in Indonesia from 2006,2 and an ADB sector report on accountability and audit in 
Indonesia.3  The  assessment  also  draws  on  the  ongoing  policy  dialogue  and  advisory  services

B. 
 

Reform Priorities: Achievements, Challenges and the Way Forward 

1. 

Improving Results-Orientation in State Budget Planning and Development 

 
6. 
To  facilitate  policy-based  budgeting,  the  Government  continues  to  prioritize  the 
implementation  of  performance-based  budgeting  (PBB)  and  the  medium-term  expenditure 
framework  (MTEF).  The  Ministry  of  Finance  (MOF)  and  the  National  Development  Planning 
Agency  (BAPPENAS)  have  been  working  together  in  developing  a  road  map  for  the 
implementation of PBB in Indonesia starting from 2009, as required in the State Finance Law. 
 
7. 
Based  on  the  PFM  reform  framework  as  legislated,  BAPPENAS  and  MOF  have  started 
revising  the  existing  program  structure  used  for  planning  and  budgeting  purposes  to  align 
programs  with  organizational  structures  and  with  the  development  agenda  defined  in  the 
Medium-Term  National  Development  Plan  (RPJM).  The  new  program  structure  will  be 
incorporated  in  the  RPJM  for  2010–2014,  and  is  intended  to  be  used  during  2010  for  the 
preparation of the 2011 budget.  
 
The budget and work plans of agencies (RKA-KL) are currently being revised to simplify 
8. 
budget  submissions  and  link  them  more  closely  to  programs.  A  manual  on  planning  and 
budgeting  for  restructuring  program  within  a  PBB  framework  has  been  finalized  by  the 
Directorate  General  for  Budget  and  BAPPENAS,  and  has  been  issued  under  a  circular  signed 
jointly by the Minister of Finance and the Minister for BAPPENAS. The contents and procedures 
of this manual are now being disseminated to all budget holders. It is anticipated that the reforms 
prescribed in the manual will be implemented in the 2011 budget preparation process. Forward 
estimates at the aggregate level, based on MTEF, were introduced in the 2008 and 2009 state 
budgets. 
 
9. 
MOF is also in the process of building its capacity in strategic performance management 
based on the “balanced scorecard” performance management tool. The possibility of interfacing 
some  balanced  scorecard  indicators  with  corresponding  PBB  indicators  being  developed  to 
monitor and evaluate program implementation is being explored.  
 
10. 
Generally, a need still exists to deepen and sustain momentum in reforming Indonesia’s 
budget  system.  The  continuing  objective  is  to  make  state  budget  planning  and  development 
more results-based, and to improve links between policy, planning, and budgeting in accordance 
with the intent of the Law on State Finances. To this end, the Government’s capability to assess 
the impact of various policy decisions on key economic and fiscal indicators needs to be further 
enhanced. Also, staff in various ministries require more training in PBB and MTEF.  
 
11. 
In  terms  of  legislative  oversight,  the  House  of  Representatives'  (DPR's)  role  in  shaping 
the  state  budget  and  fiscal  policy  has  been  institutionalized  by  law.  Budget  documentation  has 
also improved significantly. The DPR’s Budget Commission is currently discussing proposals to 
enact  a  new  law  defining  the  role  and  authority  of  DPR,  including  a  proposal  to  establish  a 
parliamentary budget office.

However,  the  DPR  continues  to  face  several  structural  challenges,  particularly  in  the

DPR will thus remain an important reform goal.  
 

2. 

Improving Budget and Treasury Management 

The 

latest  challenges 

 
13. 
Though  significant  advances  have  been  made  in  the  budget  preparation  side,  actual 
expenditures  continue  to  deviate  from  plan.  Indonesia  thus  remains  committed  to  smoothing 
budget implementation and execution through modernization of the treasury system. Most of the 
regulations  to  support  the  implementation  of  the  State  Treasury  Law  of  2004  have  been 
established,  while  others  are  being  finalized.  The  design  and  implementation  of  an  automated 
treasury  and  budget  system  (SPAN)  is  ongoing.  SPAN,  as  a  crosscutting  reform,  will  increase 
the  timeliness,  reliability,  and  transparency  of  budget  disbursement  and  reporting  as  well  as 
improve  the  capability  of  managers  in  the  efficient  management  of  public  resources.  Business 
process improvements in the area of budget formulation and budget execution are underway and 
are  expected  to  be  completed  by  2011.  A  SPAN  turnkey  implementation  vendor  has  already 
been contracted (the contract was signed on 10 July 2009).  
 
14. 
A  new  Treasury  Transformation  Directorate,  which  will  focus  on  SPAN  implementation, 
has  been  established.  Ministerial  decrees  establishing  a  project  governance  system  for  SPAN 
have been issued. SPAN is projected to become operational in the central treasury beginning in 
2011,  and  will  be  rolled  out  to  provincial  treasury  offices  (KPPNs)  and  pilot  line  ministries  in 
2012,  replacing  the  multitude  of  financial  data  processing  applications  currently  used  by 
Government institutions.

Strengthening Monitoring and Evaluation of Public Expenditures and

18. 
To  ensure  more  effective  public  spending,  improved  capacity  to  analyze  the  efficiency 
and  effectiveness  of  public  spending  is  essential.  BAPPENAS  recently  established  a  separate

analytical pieces have been produced in the last few years, and efforts by BAPPENAS and MOF

bolstered.

health,  agriculture,  and  infrastructure).  A  deeper  understanding  of  spending  in  different  sectors 
should  also  enhance  the  general  capacity  of  BAPPENAS  and  line  agencies  to  implement 
performance-based budgeting.  
 

4. 

Improving the Public Procurement System 

 
20. 
Presidential  Decree  80/2003  provided  a  national  public  procurement  regulation  that 
meets  most  of  what  is  generally  regarded  as  accepted  international  practice,  including 
transparency,  open  competition,  economy,  and  efficiency.  This  decree  also  paved  the  way  for 
establishing  a  regulatory  body  for  public  procurement.  With  the  introduction  of  Presidential 
Decree 80/2003, a previous certification (“pre-qualification”) process for suppliers and providers 
of  goods  and  services  was,  in  most  instances,  abandoned  by  the  Government.  Presidential 
Decree 80/2003 also established the basis for sanctions and for complaint handling, and laid out 
requirements for certification of users. In December 2007 an independent agency, the National 
Public Procurement Agency (LKPP), that is responsible for sustainable, integrated, focused, and 
coordinated  planning  and  development  of  strategies,  policies,  and  regulations  associated  with 
the  procurement  of  goods,  works,  and  services  using  public  funds,  was  established.  This 
institution  reports  directly  to  the  President  of  Indonesia.  In  addition  to  the  chair,  who  heads 
LKPP,  and  an  executive  secretary,  there  are  four  departments,  each  headed  by  a  deputy  with 
responsibilities for (i) strategy and policy development, (ii) monitoring evaluation and information 
systems, (iii) human resources development, and (iv) legal affairs and settlement of objections. 
The LKPP is currently operational with plans for further staffing. 
 
21.  While  Presidential  Decree  80/2003  was  a  welcome  development  for  the  country,  the 
public  procurement  system  still  has  significant  regulatory  and  implementation  deficiencies. 
Progress has been slow in developing solid procurement regulations, standard tools for bidding 
documents, and procurement guidelines. Collusion and corruption in the bidding process as well 
as  concerns  over  the  efficiency  of  complaint  mechanisms  and  sanction  measures  are  still 
significant.  However,  the  most  glaring  deficiency  is  the  absence  of  professional  procurement 
management  and  weak  procurement  capacity  in  the  implementing  agencies,  especially  at  the 
provincial and district levels. 
 
22. 
The existence of these deficiencies is supported by the findings of various analytical tools 
and  reports,  such  as  the  self-diagnostic  assessment  conducted  by  the  Government  in  2007, 
which used a baseline indicators tool developed under the World Bank and OECD Development

Public procurement function and capacity building. There has been growing concern,

entire  PFM  cycle.  Projects  report  delays  and  difficulties  in  budget  preparation  and  approval,

different models for introducing central procurement units at ministries and local governments.

procurement capacity are the most important impediments. LKPP should focus its resources on 
developing a human resources strategy that can tackle the challenges in this area. The capacity 
of Government auditing agencies to carry out procurement audits must be strengthened. Another 
important  goal  should  be  to  develop  a  set  of  performance  indicators  to  monitor  procurement 
performance within implementing agencies.

35. 
Accounting  and  reporting  on  budget  execution.  Even  though  the  aggregate

cited  for  the  “disclaimer”  opinion  is  weak  internal  control  in  the  preparation  of  financial 
statements.  Improving  the  quality  of  financial  statements  is  thus  an  important  priority  for  the 
Government. 
 
Capacity  constraints  in the  line  ministries  are  the  biggest  challenge  to  improve  financial 
36. 
statements. Line ministries and subnational governments have few trained accountants and the 
quality of their work needs improvement. The Directorate General for Treasury has an ambitious 
training program in place that aims to train at least one person for each of the country’s 22,000 or

remaining  officials  are  expected  to  be  trained  by  2010.  However,  this  is  only  a  short-term 
solution; in the long term, sustained and continuous training of line ministry staff is needed. The

universities to institute  a long-term program for training accountants. However, the plans are at 
an early stage at this point.

ministries  and  subnational  governments  by  2014.  The  accounting  standards  for  accrual 
accounting have already been drafted and are currently undergoing a review.

6. 

Reforming Regional Public Financial Management 

 
47. 
Decentralization  has  provided  subnational  governments  with  significant  resources  and 
responsibilities.  More  than  one-third  of  public  spending  is  now  executed  by  subnational 
governments. This level of expenditure requires an adequate regulatory framework, together with 
sufficient PFM capacity, at the subnational level if it is to be fully effective. To address this need, 
in  2005  the  central  Government  passed  comprehensive  legislation  on  PFM  reform  at  the 
subnational  level,  with  the  aim  of  mirroring  reforms  already  being  implemented  at  the  national 
level. However, most regions lack the technical and human resource capacity to implement the 
reforms.  For  example,  subnational  governments  are  obliged  by  law  to  report  certain  fiscal  and 
financial  information  to  the  central  Government  within  a  clear  time  frame.  In  reality,  many 
subnational governments struggle to meet their deadlines for submission. 
 
48. 
Current budget allocation and disbursement practices contribute to fiscal discipline at the 
central  level  but  constrain  successful  financial  management  at  the  local  level.  Allocations  to 
individual  subnational  governments  are  formally  issued  after  the  passage  of  the  central 
Government  budget  in  October  for  the  following  year,  and  commence  through  derivative 
regulations  (e.g.,  ministerial  decrees).  While  this  may  appear  to  allow  sufficient  time  for 
subnational governments to finalize their budgets, in reality budget allocations of shared, non-tax 
revenue  (oil  and  gas)  are  frequently  issued  in  the  first  few  months  of  the  fiscal  year.  The 
allocations  are  frequently  underestimated  by  the  central  Government  and  disbursements  from 
the center to the regions are back-loaded toward the end of the fiscal year. This is because the 
transfers  in  the  final  quarter  are  based  on  actual  revenues,  which  are  usually  higher  than 
projected revenues. 
 
49. 
Subnational governments are struggling to spend their increased budgets and have built 
up  reserves  in  recent  years  for  three  main  reasons.  First,  they  often  underestimate  their 
revenues because they lack revenue management capacity. This is compounded by the Central 
Government’s under-budgeting of transfers. Second, delays in the budget approval process and 
lack  of  implementation  capacity  result  in  under-spending  of  budgeted  programs  by  subnational 
governments. Third, subnational governments may not have the capacity to spend the resources 
at  their  disposal  when  these  resources  increase  significantly  and  abruptly.  This  was  the  case 
with the 64% increase in "general allocation funds" from 2005 to 2006, which led to a significant 
increase in subnational government reserves. 
 
50. 
Some  challenges  in  addressing  PFM  constraints  at  the  subnational  level  include:  (i) 
providing  timely  estimates  from  the  sectoral  ministries  of  revenue-sharing  transfers;  (ii) building 
the  capacity  of  subnational  governments  to  manage  accumulated  reserves;  and  (iii) improving 
and  streamlining  the  budget  approval  process.  The  need  to  streamline  the  budget  approval 
process  in  particular  affects  Law  No.  33/2004,  which  stipulates  that  provincial  and  district 
budgets must be approved by the Ministry of Home Affairs and the provincial government. This 
process may be one factor that lengthens the budget approval process. 
 
51. 
central Government has implemented several reforms:

Government  to  underestimate  the  oil  price  assumption,  especially  in  relation  to  regional

letter to submit their budget before 31 March. If a subnational government has not submitted its 
budget  by  that  date,  MOF,  in  coordination  with  the  Ministry  of  Home  Affairs,  can  sanction  the 
subnational  government  by  postponing  the  transfer  of  its  "general  allocation  funds"  (25%  of 
monthly transfers) until the budget is submitted. This initiative has resulted in more timely budget 
submissions. Between 2006 and 2007, 54% of subnational governments approved their budgets 
after  March.  In  2008,  the  year  the  sanction  was  introduced,  87%  of  subnational  governments 
submitted their budgets to MOF before March.  
 
55.  MOF  can  also  assist  subnational  governments  in  managing  reserves  and  surpluses  by 
strengthening the regulatory framework for subnational financial management. In doing so, MOF 
should  develop  guidelines  for  regions  on  accumulating  and  using  reserves.  These  guidelines 
should  help  subnational  governments  use  their  reserves  more  effectively,  for  example,  by  (i) 
settling outstanding arrears, given that about 85% of subnational governments in  arrears could 
clear  these  arrears  by  drawing  on  reserves;  and  (ii)  where  subnational  governments  have 
constant  or  increasingly  high  levels  of  reserves,  using  them  to  increase  investment  in  public 
infrastructure.  
 

7. 

Governance and Anticorruption 

 
56. 
Public  confidence  in  the  Government’s  efforts  to  combat  corruption  has  been  slowly 
restored  over  the  past  few  years,  as  reflected  in  a  number  of  opinion  polls  and  corruption 
perception surveys. The Corruption Eradication Commission (KPK) continues to take the lead in 
investigating and prosecuting high-profile corruption cases. At an unprecedented level, politicians 
and  high-ranking  government  officials  are  under  investigation  or  have  been  convicted  of 
corruption, including members of Parliament, the former national police chief, former governors 
and officials of the central bank, and heads of local government. Even after the recent arrest for 
murder  of  the  chair  of  the  commission,  the  KPK  has  been  proving  its  effectiveness  as  an 
independent  law  enforcement  agency.  The  Attorney  General’s  Office  has  also  created  an 
anticorruption task force to more effectively investigate and prosecute corruption.  
 
57. 
Apart  from  stronger  enforcement  of  anticorruption  laws,  civil  service  reform  and  judicial 
reform  are  the  linchpins  of  the  Government’s  strategy  to  combat  corruption.  The  Government 
plans to expand ongoing civil service reform efforts to other agencies under the leadership of the 
Ministry  of  State  Apparatus  Reform.  While  the  ministry  still  lacks  the  capability  to  monitor, 
evaluate,  and  drive  bureaucracy  reform,  government  agencies  are  undertaking  significant 
reforms.  The  Supreme  Court,  in  particular,  has  undergone  significant  restructuring,  and  as  a

I. 

POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A. Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
 
Before the Asian financial crisis, Indonesia had been successful in fighting poverty. The poverty rate—the proportion of 
the  population  living  below  $1/day—was  reduced  from  44%  (1976)  to  11%  (1996).  However,  the  economic  crisis  in 
1997 increased the poverty rate to 23.6% in 1998. With successful macroeconomic management following the crisis, 
poverty  incidence  steadily  declined  to  15.4%  by  2008.  Although  the  decline  of  the  $1/day  poverty  rate  is  considered 
remarkable,  close  to  half  of  the  population  still  lives  below  the  $2/day  international  poverty  line  (2008).  Disparities 
across  regions  are  striking,  as  provinces  in  outlying  regions  have  poverty  rates  that  are  well  above  the  national 
average.  
  
The Medium-Term Development Plan (RPJM) for 2005–2009 focuses on poverty reduction and the achievement of the 
Millennium  Development  Goals  (MDGs).  Its  priority  areas  include  (i)  job  creation  and  poverty  reduction  programs; 
(ii) macroeconomic  stability  with  stable  prices,  fiscal  sustainability,  and  financial  sector  reforms;  (iii)  accelerating 
investments, exports, and tourism through reforms for  a  healthy  business climate and flexible markets; (iv) improved 
access  to  and  quality  of  education  and  health;  and  (v)  infrastructure  development  by  improving  the  efficiency  in 
delivering existing services and by greater private sector participation. 
 
In August 2006, the Government launched the National Program for Community Empowerment (PNPM Mandiri), which 
builds  upon  Indonesia’s  accumulated  experience  with  community-driven  development  (CDD)  programs.  The  PNPM 
aims  to  reduce  poverty  by  (i)  promoting  community  participation  in  development  planning  and  management, 
(ii) delivering basic services and infrastructure using the CDD approach, and (iii) committing to expand coverage of the 
program to all kecamatans (6,627) by 2010. DPSP-5 is in line with ADB’s Country Strategy and Program for Indonesia 
for  the  period  2006–2009,  which  aims  to  help  the  government  achieve  its  medium-term  RPJM  objectives  of  higher 
levels of pro-poor sustainable growth and achieving the MDGs. 
  
B.  Poverty Analysis                   Targeting Classification: General intervention 
1. Key Issues  
 
Indonesia’s poverty reduction strategy paper identified four major causes of poverty, including (i) lack of access to key 
social services; (ii) absence of economic opportunities, particularly in rural areas; (iii) poor infrastructure in villages; and 
(iv) inadequate access to markets. In addition, weak governance hampers further progress in addressing these major 
causes of poverty. The National Poverty Reduction Strategy considers macroeconomic stability as the foundation for 
reducing poverty and includes five basic strategies for poverty reduction: (i) broadening income-earning opportunities, 
(ii) empowering community institutions, (iii) increasing capacity at the local levels, (iv) providing social protection, and 
(v) promoting global partnerships. 
  
2. Design Features. Not applicable 

C. Poverty Impact Analysis for Policy-Based Lending  
 
DPSP-5 aims to contribute to higher pro-poor economic growth that is sustained over the medium term through three 
core  policy  areas:  (i) improved  investment  climate,  (ii)  improved  public  financial  management  and  governance,  and 
(iii) enhanced efforts to alleviate poverty. 
 
The majority of triggers under the first two core policy areas will not directly affect the income level of poor households. 
However,  it  is  expected  that  improving  the  investment  climate  and  public  financial  management  and  governance  in 
general will contribute to improved business opportunities in the informal sector, which employs about two-thirds of the 
labor force and provides the most important income earning prospects for the poor.  
 
The  third  policy  area  aims  to  strengthen  poverty  targeting  in  determining  the  size  of  community  block  grants  to 
subdistricts under the PNPM program, and to increase the average size of the block grant for the poorest subdistricts. 
Improving  the  poverty  targeting  of  the  PNPM  block  grants  will  have  unambiguously  beneficial  effects  on  the  poor—
particularly  on  poor  living  in  isolated  villages  in  less-developed  districts  that  lack  basic  services  and  infrastructure. 
Additional  support  to  improve  basic  infrastructure  in  villages  that  have  higher-than-average  poverty  levels  will  help 

 

 70 

Appendix 9 

increase the availability and accessibility of education and health services and improve income earning opportunities. 
Community  investments  under  PNPM  are  expected  to  (i)  reduce  the  time  and  costs  spent  on  obtaining  good  quality 
water, (ii) diminish the incidence and severity of waterborne diseases, (iii) increase the availability and accessibility of 
education and health services for the rural poor and near poor, (iv) improve access to services and markets, and (v) 
provide income earning opportunities and welfare through increased employment and trade. Support to build capacity 
of local administrations and communities to plan, implement, and manage infrastructure investments will promote good 
governance at the local level. More efficient and equitable provision of services to the poorest villages will contribute to 
health- and education-related MDGs. 
  

II. 

SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A.  Findings of Social Analysis  
 
As discussed above, the reforms under the first two core policy areas will have only indirect impacts on the welfare of 
poor  people.  Improving  poverty  targeting  of  the  PNPM  program  and  increasing  the  size  of  block  grants  for 
infrastructure  investments  in  the  poorest  subdistricts  will  contribute  to  improved  living  conditions  of  the  poor. 
Infrastructure investments in poor rural areas will improve access to social services and accelerate social development. 
 
Better targeting of PNPM support to improve basic infrastructure in poor villages will contribute to addressing the major 
causes  of  poverty  as  identified  in  the  National  Poverty  Reduction  Strategy  paper,  including  (i)  lack  of  access  to  key 
social  services,  (iii)  poor  infrastructure  in  villages,  and  (iv)  inadequate  links  to  markets.  Indonesia’s  infrastructure 
provision in poor rural areas is weak by regional standards. Electrification rates are the lowest in the region, while road 
networks are limited and in  poor condition. People living  in isolated areas  with poor market links lack  both economic 
opportunities and adequate levels of service delivery. More than 15% of all Indonesian villages are inaccessible all year 
round. Lack of access to quality education significantly decreases productivity, employment opportunities, and personal 
income.  Investments  in  transportation  infrastructure,  agricultural  infrastructure  (irrigation),  and  education  and  health 
facilities can significantly improve living conditions in remote areas, create the basis for economic growth, and improve 
the  welfare  of  the  local  population.  The  positive  effect  of  infrastructure  investments  on  rural  welfare  has  been 
empirically  demonstrated;  surveys  have  revealed  that  there’s  a  significant  correlation  between  the  presence  of  good 
roads and a community’s mean level of income.a  

 
Approximately 60% of the population lives in rural areas where agriculture is the main source of livelihood. One reason 
for  low  incomes  in  the  agriculture  sector  is  that  “farm  gate  prices”  are  very  low  compared  with  urban  prices  for  the 
same  goods  of  the  same  quality.  This  is  due  to  high  transport  costs  for  rural  marketable  surpluses  over  poor  quality 
roads. Transport costs are even higher for non-motor-vehicle transport methods in areas where roads are absent. In a 
rapid assessment of causes of poverty in five of Indonesia’s districts, villagers in isolated areas identified high transport 
costs  as  a  major  cause  of  poverty.  New  roads  in  previously  unserved  agricultural  areas  can  significantly  lower 
transaction costs and hence raise farm gate prices, which will mean higher incomes for people in the agriculture sector, 
the poorest group of the population.  
 

B.  Consultation and Participation 

  
During  preparation,  regular  consultations  were  held  with  key  stakeholders  (government  officials,  NGOs  and 
development  partners).  During  implementation,  the  program  will  maintain  broad  stakeholder  participation  to  discuss 
and  review  reform  efforts.  The  Government’s  National  Community  Empowerment  Program  (PNPM)  supports 
community  empowerment  and  strengthens  local  capacity  and  governance  to  implement  infrastructure  investments. 
The  Government  has  engaged  extensively  with  civil  society  on  tax  and  investment  law  reforms.  The  entire  set  of 
DPSP-5 policy actions will likely feature in discussions with Parliament.

C. Gender and Development 

1.  Key Issues.  

 
The  country  gender  assessment  identified  four  key  themes  through  a  consultative  process:  (i)  the  impact  of 
decentralization  on  gender,  (ii)  women’s  inadequate  representation  in  political  decision\  making,  (iii)  violence  against 
women,  and  (iv)  women  and  international  migration.  While  Indonesia  has  made  progress  over  the  years,  gender 
inequalities persist. Indonesia was ranked 111 out of 182 economies in the United Nation's human development index 
in  2007  and  93  out  of  155  in  the  gender  development  index.  In  2007,  women’s  labor  force  participation  was  40%, 
compared with 80% for men. The shift to regional autonomy under the decentralization law has already shown potential 

 

 Appendix 9 

 
71

for increased participation of women in local governance.  

 
2.  Key Actions.  

Drawing  a  comprehensive  conclusion  on  issues  related  to  gender  and  income  poverty  in  Indonesia  is  difficult,  as 
consistent,  disaggregated  data  by  sex  is  not  available.  DPSP-5  will  create  indirect  gender  impacts.  Improved  poverty 
targeting  of public spending  will increase  women’s access to essential services for achieving MDG targets, including 
reducing  child  and  maternal  mortality.  Improvement  of  financial  management  systems  and  governance,  through 
increased transparency and accountability at all levels, will provide civil society with the basic information necessary to 
monitor  government  actions  and  empower  men  and  women  in  communities  to  participate  in  policy  and  budget 
decisions. To the extent that policies under DPSP increase credit to micro, small, and medium enterprises, the program 
would have an indirect beneficial impact on women considering their predominant role in microenterprises. 
 
The community-driven development approach used by the Government's PNPM program will ensure that perspectives of 
both men  and  women are represented in planning,  designing,  and implementing village  infrastructure investments. The 
community implementation organizations’ executive committees will include at least two women, and at least 40% of the 
total membership will be women. Experience from the PNPM Mandiri reveal that the number of women on the committees 
varies from few women to entirely women, depending on the circumstances of individual villages.
